program_name: The Art of Storytelling with Pixar: In Person Learning Circle
program_description:
THE ART OF STORYTELLING LEARNING CIRCLES

How would you tell the story of your community? Strengthen your storytelling skills with a learning circle this fall!

Do you know you can take an online course at the library in a learning circle? A learning circle is a study group for learners who want to complete online courses, together with others. This is a free opportunity for adults to learn new skills with others.  Learning Circles are presented as a multi-week courses, and you should plan to attend each of the classes. 

  Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. This course will take place in person and capacity is limited. Registration is required and COVID-19 safety protocols will be followed.


This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Research Your Family History with the Polish Genealogical Society of America
program_description:
Curious about your ancestors? Want to map your family tree? Robert Pine, the President of the Polish Genealogical Society of America, will provide a step-by-step introduction to sleuthing out your family background starting here in the US, then how to leap the ocean to research Polish records from home. Learn how to discover who, when, what and where; and how to transform your family tree into family history. All are welcome! This workshop is geared toward folks just getting started in genealogy or anyone looking for a fun refresher.

program_name: Grab and Go: Wianek Flower Crown
program_description:
Celebrate Polish American Heritage Month by making a Wianek, or flower crown. A Wianek is an accessory that is worn in Poland for special occasions such as holidays, parades, weddings and other festivals.

Our grab and go kit has everything you need to make your own Wianek Flower Crown! Stop by the Independence Branch to pick up a kit during regular branch hours, while supplies last.

program_name: Information Session on Careers in Welding and Advanced Manufacturing!
program_description:
Looking for a career with sustainable wages and career advancement? Come learn about careers in Welding and Advanced Manufacturing! Jane Addams Resource Corporation (JARC) 's Careers in Manufacturing Programs provide free job training and job placement services that can help adults find employment in the manufacturing sector with skills in Computer Numerical Control (CNC), Welding, or Mechanical Assembly. JARC provides financial coaching, public benefits screening, and transportation assistance throughout training.

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: And Then There Were None
program_description:
Join King Branch for a discussion of Agatha Christie's And Then There Were None. 

"Ten strangers are lured to an isolated island mansion off the Devon coast by a mysterious 'U.N. Owen.' At dinner a recorded message accuses each of them in turn of having a guilty secret, and by the end of the night one of the guests is dead. Stranded by a violent storm, and haunted by a nursery rhyme counting down one by one...as one by one...they begin to die. Which among them is the killer and will any of them survive?" Provided by publisher. 

While supplies last, copies of this title are available at the King Branch circulation desk.

program_name: How to Zoom: Intro to Online Meetings
program_description:
Have you been invited to a Zoom meeting, or have you seen an online class that you'd like to take via Zoom? In this era of social distancing, many groups are choosing to meet virtually using Zoom, rather than in person.

Zoom is an application used to hold online virtual meetings. You can use Zoom on a smartphone, a tablet, a laptop, or a desktop computer (if your device has a camera, speakers, and a microphone). This class will cover the basics of how to connect as a participant, as well as how to set up a meeting as a host. We will also cover options for how you appear, sound, and are able to share your screen during a Zoom meeting.

How to Attend

Spoken word poetry is a word-based performance art where speakers engage in powerful self-expression by sharing their views on particular topics. Poet Kerry B will conduct a spoken word poetry workshop for adults age 18 and up. All levels of experience are welcomed in this supportive literary environment. Topics covered will include stage presence, performance poetry writing, and poetry slams. Videos will be shared as well as prompts for participants to draft their own spoken word piece.

Poet Kerry B is an award-winning spoken word artist and author who uses hip-hop and jazz influences for his poetry. Participating in open mics and readings throughout the nation, he is known for his rhyme scheme and style. His poetry is recognized to carry powerful messages, along with a passionate delivery. He is the author of the poetry books Soul Appetizer: A Sampler, An Open Table, and Surviving Myself. He has released multiple spoken word albums, including the award-winning Kadence of a Poetic Gentleman. Poet Kerry B is the co-owner of the poetry venue, the Majesty Lounge, and currently teaches English and creative writing at Miles College.

This event takes place on Zoom. Register 1 day before the event. Only one registration per household is necessary. program_name: The Competition for the Harold Washington Library Center: 30th Anniversary Commemoration!
program_description:
Chicago Public Library's Harold Washington Library Center opened to the public on October 7, 1991. Join us as we celebrate the 30th anniversary of the opening of the largest municipal library in the U.S. with a program presented by Patrick Steffes of Docomomo/US Chicago.

The Harold Washington Library Center (HWLC) is also one of the largest public Postmodern buildings in the world. By the time HWLC opened in 1991, Postmodernism would be rapidly falling out of favor as an architectural style, leading to its often-maligned and overlooked place in Chicago architectural history and perception.

Unlike the far better known architectural competition for the Chicago Tribune in 1922, the 1988 Chicago central library competition is nearly completely forgotten. This competition, unlike the Tribune, was in no way influential, with none of the losing designs known to have been celebrated, copied, or widely reproduced in books or online in the decades since.

Notably, only six architectural firms including Lohan & Associates, Murphy/Jahn, SOM, Ricardo Legoretta and Arthur Erickson would enter in one of the highest profile and lucrative global architectural competitions of the 1980s.

In addition to the competition and the winning entry, this presentation will discuss in depth the drastic changes
Chicago’s South Loop has experienced since the nineteenth century. We will also discuss how HWLC has revitalized this long struggling area.

Experience many unknown and unpublished images of South State Street and the South Loop, including never-published photographs showing the current HWLC site and the surrounding area going back more than 100 years.

Photo shown above: Harold Washington Library Center proposal submitted by The Chicago Library Team (Murphy / Jahn and Paschen Contractors). Photo credit: The Chicago Architectural Journal 7, 1989.

Mayor Harold Washington was born on April 15, 1922 and this program is presented as part of centennial celebrations commemorating the 100th anniversary of his birth on April 15, 2022.

program_name: The Art of RAS (Rhyme, Alliteration, Storytelling)
program_description:
This program, led by poet and author Ashlee Connors, seeks to discuss ways to implement effective techniques in poetry writing specifically rhyme and alliteration. We will dispel the belief that rhyme is bad in poetry or makes you a bad writer and watch an example of what it looks like in performance. We will learn what alliteration is and the effect it has on poetry. Lastly, we will create a word bank either from the example we listened to or where facilitator feels led to tell an important story that revisits us. Participants will get 15 minutes to brainstorm and write as much as they can. If time allows, we will hear some drafts.

Ashlee Connors is an award-winning poet, author, editor, and spoken word artist. Her work is a wide eyed exploration of love, mental health, sexuality, and motherhood - the joy of survival and the courage of healing. She is a founding member the Counter Collective, an arts organization dedicated to creating safe spaces for artists and currently serves on the executive committee of the Women of the World Poetry Festival, which aims to highlight and amplify voices of women and non-binary writers across the globe.

program_name: Altar-ing: A Latinx Creative Nonfiction Zine Workshop
program_description:
In this two-part workshop series that culminates with the publication of a collaborative zine, we will learn the history of altars, the science of remembering, how creative nonfiction writing and Latinx music activates ancestral/cultural healing, and how we can archive ourselves digitally and in real life as an antidote to erasure.

We will document memories, build musical soundtracks for our muertos, create an altar, and collect our work in an archival zine published by Chicago Public Library.

From San Antonio to Chicago, and all around the world, /a cultura cura. Our cultural traditions, ancestral knowledge, and creative resilience is worth celebrating, honoring, and remembering.

Bonnie Ilza Cisneros is a fourth-generation Tejana educator in a line of South Texas teachers. Bonnie holds a Creative Writing MFA from Texas State University, is a member of the Macondo Writers Workshop, and was awarded a NALAC artist grant in 2018. Moonlighting as DJ Despeinada, she spins all-vinyl soundscapes of the borderlands. Bonnie’s poems and essays appear in El Retorno, Chicana/Latina Studies, Porter House Review, River Teeth, and El Placazo Barrio Newspaper. Her essay, “The Ana Files” was anthologized in Contemporary Creative Nonfiction, and she led a series of workshops entitled Altar-ing at the San Antonio Public Library where she edited a collection of participants’ home altars, ancestral recipes, and personal playlists in a zine published by the Latino Collection and Resource Center. 

Recently, she has been curating Siempre Verde, a quarantine DJ residency, art project, and journalistic experiment at Evergreen Garden, lecturing and teaching online workshops, recording radio shows for WFMU, and trying to stay healthy and creative in San Antonio with her partner, two m’ijas, and a flock of three gallinas. You can learn more about her work on her digital archive, www.bonniecisneros.com

Monty and Rose 2: The World of Monty and Rose is a feature-length documentary about the endangered Piping Plovers that have nested at Chicago’s Montrose Beach the past three summers. The film tells the birds’ story as they struggle toward nesting success and face a music festival that would take place within feet of their nest.

Bob Dolgan created his first film, Monty and Rose, as a volunteer plover monitor in Chicago in 2019. He is a past Board Member of Chicago Ornithological Society and writes the This Week in Birding newsletter. He works as a consultant to nonprofit organizations in the areas of strategic planning and communications.

Monty and Rose 2 is partially supported by a grant from the Illinois Arts Council. Title Sponsor is Redstart Birding, a small, Ohio-based, female-owned business powered by birders, and Platinum Sponsor is Openlands, which protects the natural and open spaces of northeastern Illinois. More information is available at www.montyandrose.net.

program_name: Chicago History Book Club: Louis Sullivan
program_description:
After the catastrophic fire that destroyed the city, Louis Sullivan was considered a guiding light of Chicago's rebirth, helping to design several notable buildings. He sought to create new architectural concepts that would set the United States apart from its European past. He was hailed as a master craftsman for his Transportation building during the 1893 Columbian Exposition; yet his uncompromising ideals estranged him from both friends and clients. Sullivan wound up dying alone and forgotten in the 1920s, but his artistic legacy influenced dozens of architects, including Frank Lloyd Wright. 

Join Edgewater Branch for a discussion on his life by reading either The Autobiography of An Idea or Louis Sullivan: His Life and Work. These titles will be available at the Circulation Desk or can be sent to other branches for pick-up. This program is a partnership with the Edgewater Historical Society.

program_name: Adult Crafting: Learn Origami with Esteban
program_description:
Join the North Pulaski Branch and our neighborhood origami man, Esteban, to learn origami basics. Esteban will lead us through everything from the beginner's crane to more medium/intermediate animals and even some Halloween inspired origami. 

Please visit North Pulaski for a grab and go kit for a set of pre-cut 8" x 8" paper for the origami sessions, while supplies last. If you would like a kit sent to your local branch, please email John and let him know how many and which branch. Each kit will contain 10 sheets of paper (limit 5).  If you'd like to use your own paper at home, please cut 8" x 8" squares to begin.

program_name: Walking With Wolking: A Buena Park Historical Tour with Alex Wolking
program_description:
Long time Buena Park resident and local architecture and history buff Alex Wolking will lead us on a tour to explore the rich history and architecture of Buena Park. From the early days of Buena Park's origins, to the design and storied pasts of coveted Hutchinson Street mansions. You will learn, laugh, and experience some of the best architectural eye candy Uptown has to offer!

Alex Wolking is a resident and enthusiast of all things Uptown. In addition to his real estate career, he is a board member of Landmarks Illinois and is involved with a number of Uptown-based community organizations. Alex brings a high-spirited energy and wealth of knowledge to every tour.

Please note that this is a walking tour that will last approximately one hour and fifteen minutes. We will meet in front of the library before departing.

This program is limited to 30 participants. Please register online or by calling the branch at 312-744-8400.

(George Maher Home, Hutchinson Street,1902 photo credit: Jameson Sotheby's International Realty)

Join CPL Head Clerk and cook extraordinaire, Ms. Betty, as she explores Latinx culture through food in this new program, ¡Que Sabroso! (How Delicious). Ms. Betty will make chiles en nogada, one of Mexico's most treasured and delicious dishes. Chiles en nogada are stuffed poblano chiles topped with a walnut-based cream sauce, called nogada, pomegranate seeds, and parsley. Patrons will also receive a special musical playlist and booklist of Mexican cookbooks available at Chicago Public Library. Recipe is listed below.

10 signos: el Alzheimer y otras demencias causan cambios en la memoria, el pensamiento y el comportamiento que interfieren con la vida diaria. Únase a nosotros para aprender sobre 10 señales de advertencia comunes y qué observar en usted y en los demás. El programa de una hora cubrirá los cambios típicos relacionados con la edad, las señales de advertencia comunes de la enfermedad de Alzheimer, cómo acercarse a alguien sobre problemas de memoria, detección temprana, los beneficios de un diagnóstico y el proceso de diagnóstico y los recursos de la Asociación de Alzheimer.

Este programa será en español.

Cómo Puede Participar

Este programa sera virtual usando Zoom. Registrese por lo menos 24 horas antes del evento. Solo una registración por familia es necesaria. Recibirá por correo electrónico el enlace de la reunión de Zoom unas horas antes de que empiece el evento.Al registrarse usted acepta los términos de uso de la biblioteca: Library Use Guidelines.

¿Tiene preguntas de como participar en nuestros eventos virtuales? Vaya a Preguntas y Respuestas.

'Tis the season for all things creepy! Join us for a virtual discussion on the monster who preyed on Californians from 1976 to 1986. While this killer is known by many aliases, he is widely known as the ‘Golden State Killer.’ No reading is necessary to attend the discussion group, but we’ll be using Michelle McNamara’s book, I'll Be Gone in the Dark, as a main resource. We’ll talk about the murder timeline and what it takes to understand the mind of a killer.

Discover further resources for exploration on the Golden State Killer:

In the Footsteps of a Killer - L.A. Magazine article by Michelle McNamara - Requires CPL card to access

I'll Be Gone in the Dark - HBO Documentary

Episode 118: Golden State Serial Killer Caught My Favorite Murder podcast

program_name: Grab and Go: Wianek Flower Crown
program_description:

Our grab and go kit has everything you need to make your own Wianek Flower Crown! Stop by the Albany Park Branch to pick up a kit during regular branch hours, while supplies last.

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Hidden Valley Road
program_description:
Join the Clearing Branch for a discussion of Hidden Valley Road by Robert Kolker. Copies of the book are available at the front circulation desk.

Don and Mimi Galvin seemed to be living the American dream. After World War II, Don's work with the Air Force brought them to Colorado, where their twelve children perfectly spanned the baby boom: the oldest born in 1945, the youngest in 1965. In those years, there was an established script for a family like the Galvins--aspiration, hard work, upward mobility, domestic harmony--and they worked hard to play their parts. But behind the scenes was a different story: psychological breakdown, sudden shocking violence, hidden abuse. By the mid-1970s, six of the ten Galvin boys, one after another, were diagnosed as schizophrenic. How could all this happen to one family?

What took place inside the house on Hidden Valley Road was so extraordinary that the Galvins became one of the first families to be studied by the National Institute of Mental Health. Their story offers a shadow history of the science of schizophrenia, from the era of institutionalization, lobotomy, and the schizophrenogenic mother to the search for genetic markers for the disease, always amid profound disagreements about the nature of the illness itself. And unbeknownst to the Galvins, samples of their DNA informed decades of genetic research that continues today, offering paths to treatment, prediction, and even eradication of the disease for future generations.

With clarity and compassion, bestselling and award-winning author Robert Kolker uncovers one family's unforgettable legacy of suffering, love, and hope.

program_name: Neighborhoods in the Archives: Morgan Park and Washington Heights
program_description:
Archivists from CPL Special Collections and the Vivian G. Harsh Research Collection use archival artifacts and documents to discuss the history of the Morgan Park and Washington Heights neighborhoods. Special Collections will cover the early story of Morgan Park's annexation to the city of Chicago, a process that is discussed and debated in Bedrock Faith. Harsh will bring the story to more recent times, highlighting the Morgan Park Co-op Credit Union (the oldest African American credit union in Chicago) and the Washington Heights Community Organization (formed in 1966 for the upkeep and economic development and growth of the area).

Tune in for a special series of videos featuring archival material related to Chicago’s neighborhoods. CPL archivists and librarians showcase secrets and treasures from the archives that highlight our city’s history.


How to Attend:

This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

Accessibility

program_name: The Great Chicago Fire: Chicago Stories Film Screening
program_description:
Join Woodson Library to discuss The Great Chicago Fire: Chicago Stories, the documentary film from WTTW.

On October 10, 1871, the citizens of Chicago faced an unrecognizable landscape. Just 48 hours earlier, there had been a vibrant city on the rise, with ornate civic buildings, grand hotels and cultural institutions. But after the Great Chicago Fire, there was nothing but a smoking pile of rubble nearly four miles long and a mile wide.

How did a routine fire become a massive disaster? Could the city possibly recover? And how did tensions between the city’s elite and the immigrant poor lead to the wrong person being wrongfully accused of starting the blaze?

program_name: Thrifty Girl Kicks Your Financial Butt!
program_description:
Do you worry 24/7 about money? Do you struggle paycheck to paycheck? Do you think you'll be stuck renting 'til hell freezes over?  Thrifty Girl can help!

Alexis Steinkamp, author of the book, Thrifty Girl Kicks Your Finanial Butt! gives you everything you need to get a grip on your finances. In this book, you will learn step-by-step how to light a fire under your financial butt: organize your finances, set goals, tackle debt and live the life of a thrifty person! 

Consider yourself warned! This no-nonsense personal finance book will change your life!

Thrifty Girl’s book is a workbook—to get the most out of this program, download the worksheets at:

알바니팍 도서관 한국어 북클럽에 초대합니다. 이번 달에는 치마마다 응고지 아디치에의 보라색 히비스커스를 읽고 토론합니다. 나이지리아의 엄격한 상류 가정 출신 소녀의 정신적 독립에 대한 이야기입니다.

Canva is a robust cloud-based digital design tool that can be used to make anything from posts for social media to event flyers, and even stylized resumes. It is a great resource if you are interested in dipping your toes into digital design in a user-friendly way.

This short class will demonstrate navigating Canva and getting started with different features and format types. We will complete a follow-along tour followed with independent work time at the end if you'd like to test your new skills and get feedback and tips.

If you would like to follow along, please create an account on Canva.com prior to attending this virtual session. There is a paid version, but the free version is amazing and has plenty of options for beginners to more advanced users.

This event is hosted by Rachael from the Richard M. Daley Branch who enjoys digital design and exploring open source tools like Canva.

program_name: Graphic Novel Book Group: La Perdida
program_description:
Welcome to the Logan Square Branch Graphic Novel Book Club! Books are available at the Logan Square Branch Circulation Desk.

Join us in celebrating Latinx Heritage Month as we read and discuss Jessica Abel's La Perdida.

"Carla Olivares, a young Mexican-American woman, goes to Mexico City to try to get in touch with her Mexican side. She's got her own, distorted ideas about what that means, and her annoyance with an old boyfriend who's leading his idea of the romantic expatriate life (by hanging out exclusively with other expats) makes her even more nervous about coming off like an outsider. She starts hanging out with a bunch of local lowlifes and blowhards who feed her guilt about being a privileged 'conquistadora' They talk big (about stardom and revolution), but barely scrape by on petty crime-which eventually becomes not so petty, and sucks Carla into a vortex of fear and violence." --Publisher's Weekly

program_name: Adult Nonfiction Book Discussion: The Happiness Project
program_description:
Please join us for a lively discussion of the book The Happiness Project by Gretchen Rubin.

“A cross between the Dali Lama’s The Art of Happiness and Elizabeth Gilbert’s Eat, Pray, Love, seamlessly buttressed by insights from sources as diverse as psychological scientists, novelists, poets, and philosophers, Gretchen Rubin’s book is one that readers will revisit again and again as they seek to fulfill their own dreams for happiness.

program_name: Get to Work with the ICNC
program_description:
Industrial Council of Nearwest Chicago (ICNC) will provide job seekers access to job opportunities and coaching on job search techniques and resumes. In addition, they can refer individuals to job training providers and small business resources.

ICNC is a partner of The Hatchery Chicago. Together they will be offering a culinary training program for young adults. ICNC works with start-ups and established businesses in industries such as manufacturing, food/beverage, apparel/textiles, and more.

Registration is recommended but not required.

Come to the South Chicago Branch and pick up a grab and go kit.

Every other Wednesday a different craft or stem activity is featured. Supplies are limited; kits are distributed on a first come, first served basis. Kits can be picked up between 2:00 p.m. and 7:30 p.m., and are distributed while supplies last.

These activities are appropriate for children 4 to 13.

Are you tired of dead-end jobs? Ready to start building a rewarding career? The Greater West Town Training Partnership (GWTP) can help. Meet with Lorena to learn about the opportunities available through GWTP for technical skills training and job placement.

program_name: Learning Circle: The Art of Storytelling with Pixar
program_description:
How would you tell the story of your community? Strengthen your storytelling skills with a learning circle this fall!

Do you know you can take an online course at the library in a learning circle? A learning circle is a study group for learners who want to complete online courses, together with others. This is a free opportunity for adults to learn new skills with others. This season, we will offer virtual, in person, and hybrid learning circle options for your convenience. Advance registration is required and free Zoom software is needed for virtual programs. Learning Circles are presented as a multi-week courses, and you should plan to attend each of the classes.

Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required.

    • Wednesdays, September 1 through October 13, 2:00 pm - 3:30 pm
      • Session 1: Sep. 1 - We are all storytellers
      • Session 2: Sep. 8 - Character
      • Session 3: Sep. 15 - Story structure
      • Session 4: Sep. 29 - Visual language
      • Session 5: Oct. 6 - Film grammar
      • Session 6: Oct. 13 - Pitching and feedback

    Accessibility

    Automatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

program_description:

At the virtual drop-in studio, you can use any arts or crafts materials you have on hand to make whatever you’d like, though there will be a weekly theme at the ready if you need some inspiration. Come learn from and share art/craft skills or creative tips with other participants and enjoy a supportive arts environment for makers of all skill levels.

program_name: Film Screening: Burnt Oranges by Silvia A. Malagrino
program_description:
From 1976 to 1983 Argentina underwent the most brutal dictatorship of the country's history. To this day
Argentineans are confronting the legacies of the state terrorism of the '70s.Director Silvia Malagrino, in a joint effort with journalist/writer Monica Flores Correa, returns to Buenos Aires to film twenty-two years after leaving Argentina during the so-called “Dirty War.” Vividly depicting contemporary life in the city and recalling events surrounding the time of the military repression in the ’70s, Burnt Oranges presents compelling accounts of resistance and transformation.

Burnt Oranges combines a poetic personal narrative with traditional documentary interviews, historical and re-created footage. The narration is based on factual letters written by the director Silvia Malagrino and writer Monica Flores Correa, both friends who fled the country at different times.Fundamental to the film are the voices of members of Argentine human rights organizations: Mothers of the Disappeared, Grandmothers of the Disappeared, HIJOS (Sons and Daughters of the Disappeared), and also governmental figures of the 1976-83 military dictatorship who explain their position. Other witnesses include the former chief editor of the Daily Buenos Aires Herald -Bob Cox, and Alicia Partnoy -a poet and a survivor of torture in a detention center. Together, these voices contribute to our understanding of core questions of human action, the potential for creation and destruction, and the necessity of accountability.

Silvia Malagrino is as an international award-winning artist, native of Buenos Aires, Argentina. She is Professor in Photography at The School of Art and Art History of the University of Illinois at Chicago. Malagrino’s practice as an artist is fluid and essentially interdisciplinary. She works with different mediums— photography, digital video, language, light and sound to represent not only issues of historical and cultural interest but also to explore in depth the fancies, the intricacies, and the idiosyncrasies of the personal imagination.

program_name: Book Discussion: The Best Polish Restaurant in Buffalo
program_description:
In celebration of Polish American Heritage Month, the Oriole Park Branch will be discussing The Best Polish Restaurant in Buffalo by William Kowalski.

"In 1908, 16-year-old Aniela leaves her native Poland for Buffalo, New York. Over the next century, her descendants take root, struggle, and thrive, with the family restaurant at the center of it all, doing their part to weave their threads into the rich tapestry that is the history of immigration in America."--Back cover.

The nation’s pre-eminent creator of parks, Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), and his sons, the Olmsted Brothers, had important ties with Chicago that have often been overlooked. In this virtual presentation, historian Julia Bachrach illuminates the Olmsted’s significant contributions to the city’s South Side parks. This program is offered in conjunction with the exhibit From Swamps to Parks: Building Chicago’s Public Spaces. It is also in honor of Olmsted200, which celebrates the 200th anniversary of Olmsted’s birth, and the Chicago Architecture Center’s Open House Chicago, which includes an Olmsted Trail this year.

Learn more about park history in the exhibit From Swamps to Parks: Building Chicago's Public Spaces, on display now at Harold Washington Library Center in the 9th floor Exhibit Hall.

program_name: Book Discussion: The Library at the Edge of the World﻿﻿
program_description:
Join the Assistive Resources Center Accessible Audiobook Discussion Group for a dial-in phone discussion of The Library at the Edge of the World by Felicity Hayes-McCoy.

Librarian Hanna Casey returns to her hometown on the west coast of Ireland after divorcing her cheating husband. She renovates a small cottage and takes over the route for the mobile library van, but there are developments afoot that could ruin the life she is trying to build.

How to Attend 
This event takes place by phone and especially welcomes patrons with visual disabilities. To register for this event, please call 312-747-4001 for access information. An accessible digital audiobook is available to those who qualify via Illinois State Library Talking Book and Braille Service.

When registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines.

program_name: Virtual Tour of Poland, the Land of Fields, with Robert Pine
program_description:
Poland is a country with an amazing history of triumph over adversity and tyrannical oppression. It is a land with rich traditions, abundant cultural heritage and home to seventeen UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Robert Pine will share from his personal experiences across Poland why this country is an overlooked gem as a travel destination. From impressive natural beauty, to delectable cuisine and spectacular art, this presentation is one not to miss!

program_name: Get to Work with the ICNC
program_description:
The Industrial Council of Nearwest Chicago (ICNC) refers individuals to job training providers and small business resources.
  • Create a new resume
  • Update your resume
  • Discover local lob opportunities
  • Discover local training programs

ICNC is a partner of The Hatchery Chicago. Together, they offer a culinary training program for young adults.

ICNC works with start-ups and established businesses in industries such as manufacturing, food/beverage, apparel/textiles and more.

Registration is recommended but not required.

program_description:

program_name: Mi Libro y Yo Spanish Book Club for Kids
program_description:

Pase por la biblioteca Chicago Lawn para obtener una copia del libro o puede pedir el libro en línea y enviarlo a su biblioteca más cercana. También trabajaremos en una actividad.

Este programa será en español y es recomendado para niños de 6 a 9 años.

Cómo Puede Participar

Este programa sera virtual usando Zoom. Registrese por lo menos 24 horas antes del evento. Solo una registración por familia es necesaria. program_name: Korean Americans in Chicago: From Lawrence to the Suburbs
program_description:
Mr. Jin Lee, president of JLEE & Associated, a consulting firm specializing in government and non-profit organizations, and a current elected school board member of Maine Township High School District 207, will give a lecture on Korean Americans in Chicago - how the community formed, what they did for a living, how they keep their cultural heritage, and where they have been moving. This event is co-sponsored by CPL’s Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Committee.

How to Attend:
This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

Accessibility
Automatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Altar-ing: A Latinx Creative Nonfiction Zine Workshop
program_description:
In this two-part workshop series that culminates with the publication of a collaborative zine, we will learn the history of altars, the science of remembering, how creative nonfiction writing and Latinx music activates ancestral/cultural healing, and how we can archive ourselves digitally and in real life as an antidote to erasure.

We will document memories, build musical soundtracks for our muertos, create an altar, and collect our work in an archival zine published by Chicago Public Library.

From San Antonio to Chicago, and all around the world, /a cultura cura. Our cultural traditions, ancestral knowledge, and creative resilience is worth celebrating, honoring, and remembering.

Bonnie Ilza Cisneros is a fourth-generation Tejana educator in a line of South Texas teachers. Bonnie holds a Creative Writing MFA from Texas State University, is a member of the Macondo Writers Workshop, and was awarded a NALAC artist grant in 2018. Moonlighting as DJ Despeinada, she spins all-vinyl soundscapes of the borderlands. Bonnie’s poems and essays appear in El Retorno, Chicana/Latina Studies, Porter House Review, River Teeth, and El Placazo Barrio Newspaper. Her essay, “The Ana Files” was anthologized in Contemporary Creative Nonfiction, and she led a series of workshops entitled Altar-ing at the San Antonio Public Library where she edited a collection of participants’ home altars, ancestral recipes, and personal playlists in a zine published by the Latino Collection and Resource Center. 

Recently, she has been curating Siempre Verde, a quarantine DJ residency, art project, and journalistic experiment at Evergreen Garden, lecturing and teaching online workshops, recording radio shows for WFMU, and trying to stay healthy and creative in San Antonio with her partner, two m’ijas, and a flock of three gallinas. You can learn more about her work on her digital archive, www.bonniecisneros.com

How to Attend

Join Albany Park Branch's book club as we discuss Disappearing Earth by Julia Phillips.

"One August afternoon, on the shoreline of the Kamchatka peninsula at the northeastern edge of Russia, two girls--sisters, eight and eleven--go missing. In the ensuing weeks, then months, the police investigation turns up nothing. Echoes of the disappearance reverberate across a tightly woven community, with the fear and loss felt most deeply among its women. Taking us through a year in Kamchatka, Disappearing Earth enters with astonishing emotional acuity the worlds of a cast of richly drawn characters, all connected by the crime: a witness, a neighbor, a detective, a mother."

program_name: One Book, One Chicago Discussion: Bedrock Faith
program_description:
Join Brighton Park Branch for a virtual book discussion of Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May.

Gerald "Stew Pot" Reeves returns to his mother's home in Chicago's Parkland neighborhood after fourteen years in prison. His return provokes fear and suspicion among the residents especially when he claims he has had a religious awakening. With his pit bull, John the Baptist, his mentor, Brother Crown, and a few others who believe in him, he sets off to change his neighborhood for the better.

program_description:

Come explore the Harold Washington Library Center as part of Open House Chicago. Pick up a self-guided tour brochure in the ground floor Grand Lobby and explore at your own pace. 

Harold Washington Library Center is the central library location of the Chicago Public Library. Opened in 1991, it was named in honor of Mayor Harold Washington, Chicago's first African American Mayor. The enormous building’s red stone exterior references other iconic Chicago buildings such as the Monadnock and The Rookery, but the enormous rooftop acroteria, in the form of copper owls, give it a distinctive presence. Always a hub of activity, the library houses over 1.2 million holdings, an award-winning Maker Lab, the renovated Thomas Hughes Children's Library, cutting-edge Teen YouMedia space, dozens of works of art by notable artists, rotating exhibits, music practice rooms, and a beautiful Winter Garden.

program_name: The Budlong Writers Read: Love, Death, and Everything in Between
program_description:
Pour yourself a cup of hot apple cider and settle in for a cozy autumn afternoon of stories and poems as the Budlong Writers read from their newly published anthology, Love, Death, and Everything in Between. 

Fear is in the air. Writing these words, musing how true this actually is, I mentally applaud the writers of this collection for either ignoring or confronting or distilling this fear. Here you'll find the safe space where they have emptied their hearts. --Donna Pecore, Budlong Writing Workshop Facilitator

Come explore the Harold Washington Library Center as part of Open House Chicago. Pick up a self-guided tour brochure in the ground floor Grand Lobby and explore at your own pace. 

Harold Washington Library Center is the central library location of the Chicago Public Library. Opened in 1991, it was named in honor of Mayor Harold Washington, Chicago's first African American Mayor. The enormous building’s red stone exterior references other iconic Chicago buildings such as the Monadnock and The Rookery, but the enormous rooftop acroteria, in the form of copper owls, give it a distinctive presence. Always a hub of activity, the library houses over 1.2 million holdings, an award-winning Maker Lab, the renovated Thomas Hughes Children's Library, cutting-edge Teen YouMedia space, dozens of works of art by notable artists, rotating exhibits, music practice rooms, and a beautiful Winter Garden.

Bingo, Bingo, Bingo! Do you love Bingo? If so, join us for a fun-filled afternoon playing our favorite game and for a chance to win cool prizes.

program_name: Grab and Go: Wianek Flower Crown
program_description:
Celebrate Polish American Heritage Month by making a Wianek, or flower crown. A Wianek is an accessory that is worn in Poland for special occasions such as holidays, parades, weddings and other festivals.

Our grab and go kit has everything you need to make your own Wianek Flower Crown! Stop by the Back of the Yards Branch to pick up a kit during regular library hours, while supplies last.

program_name: Paint Your Story: Your Voice on Canvas
program_description:
Polish artist Patricia Stepniak uses mixed media and Polish folk tales to inspire kids to create their own picture stories using watercolors, oil pastels, ink and scrapbooking materials. All supplies provided!

A graduate of the Fine Arts School in Poland, Patricia Stepniak’s whole life is centered around sharing her artistic talents with the world. Patricia is well versed in many different areas of the fine arts, including painting, designing and sculpting among others. She teaches, creates art and uses her knowledge to train the next generation of artists at her own studio – PatriciaARTStudio.

This event is sponsored by the Polish American Services Committee in celebration of Polish American Heritage Month.

program_name: Rise Up: Inspiring the Next Generation of Diverse Lawyers
program_description:
Have you thought about becoming a lawyer? Are you passionate about social justice and equal rights? Come meet lawyers and judges from the Cook County Bar Association as we present “Rise Up: Inspiring the Next Generation of Diverse Lawyers.” 

Join us to learn about the various skills and tools to become a lawyer. We hope to inspire the next generation to pursue careers in law and increase diversity in the legal profession. During the presentation, lawyers will share several books to highlight key principles that propelled them forward, civil rights issues that persist in our country today, and the importance of diversity.

Come learn about the inspiration that led attorneys and judges into the field of Law. The following titles will be highlighted: 

Becoming

Thurgood Marshall

The Color of Law

The New Jim Crow

This will be a community storytelling event where lawyers will be able to field questions from the audience on their motivations and careers. Please join us.

Researchers, experts and readers join a panel discussion on the impact of the One Book, One Chicago program over the last two decades. What can we learn about Chicago’s readers? How does a citywide reading program create community? These questions and more will be discussed. Panelists include John Shanahan, Associate Dean & Director of Liberal Studies at DePaul University and lead researcher of the Reading Chicago Reading study, Jennifer Lizak, coordinator of the One Book, One Chicago program, and Chicago author and teacher Kathleen Rooney.

How to Attend:

This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel and CPL's Facebook page. You'll be able to ask questions during the event as well! Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

NFTs are tokenized digital artworks for sale in exchange for cryptocurrency. If you’re a traditional artist, there are a lot of new things to learn in order to create in this new medium. This presentation will cover the basic knowledge an artist needs to know to feel more confident getting started with NFTs. This presentation is for educational purposes only, and it is not intended as financial advice.

Melanie Adcock is a classically trained fine artist who currently works in the tech industry as a writer about Artificial Intelligence related topics. She has sold over 100 NFTs and has been making digital art for over 10 years. She is active in the local Chicago technology community and serves as the host of radio broadcast, Tech Scene Chicago, on 105.5 FM WLPN LP Chicago, Lumpen Radio.

program_name: Adult Mystery Book Club: The Night Bird
program_description:
Lincoln Park's Adult Mystery Book Club discusses The Night Bird by Brian Freeman.

Homicide detective Frost Easton doesn't like coincidences. When a series of bizarre deaths rock San Francisco as seemingly random women suffer violent psychotic breaks, Frost looks for a connection that leads him to psychiatrist Francesca Stein. Frankie's controversial therapy helps people erase their most terrifying memories and all the victims were her patients. As Frost and Frankie carry out their own investigations, the case becomes increasingly personal and dangerous. Long-submerged secrets surface as someone called the Night Bird taunts the pair with cryptic messages pertaining to the deaths. Soon Frankie is forced to confront strange gaps in her own memory, and Frost faces a killer who knows the detective's worst fears. As the body count rises and the Night Bird circles ever closer, a dedicated cop and a brilliant doctor race to solve the puzzle before a cunning killer claims another victim.

Copies are available at Lincoln Park Branch's Circulation Desk.

program_name: Neighborhood Tour: Postcards From The Past
program_description:
What do Chicago’s postcards tell us about the past? Or the present? Or how a community has changed? In this walk, we’ll look at 7-9 different sites to look carefully at how these places have changed since they were depicted within the postcards - it’ll be an opportunity to think about changes in the urban environment - modest and major.

Join us for virtual neighborhood tours, featuring host and urbanologist Max Grinnell, as we explore the people, places and communities that make Chicago's neighborhoods so special! 

How to Attend:

This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

Accessibility

This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: The Quiet Year – Community Storytelling and Mapmaking Game
program_description:
Using gameplay as a means of building community, join the library as we explore and play the critically acclaimed storytelling and cartography game The Quiet Year by designer Avery Alder.

The Quiet Year is a unique game built around map making and community life after a devastating event. Players will use a deck of cards that correspond to weeks of the year, with each card representing one week. Each week brings questions and decisions driven by luck, omens, and other elements that affect everyone and everything in the fictional community being built. Each of these elements are then added to a map which takes shape over the course of the year. By the end of the game, players will have collaboratively told the story one year of community life and represented it on a shared map. No need for roleplaying game experience to join, though this program is aimed towards teen and adult audiences.


How to Attend:

Ford City, one of the first modern malls in Chicago, has a long and interesting history. From it's beginnings as a Dodge Plant producing aircraft engines for World War II, a Tucker Automotive plant, a Ford Aircraft Engine Plant and finally to Ford City Mall.

Join Frank Werner, former Chief Engineer of Ford City for 47 years, as he guides us through this history with historic photos and documents. This event is sponsored by the Clear-Ridge Historical Society.

Join Lea of LT Coaching for a 60 minute lecture on How to Handle Difficult Conversations. This lecture will talk about why conflict can be a good thing and will provide framework to work through tough conversations. Communication is critical for strong relationships and having a guide to prepare you helps ensure the conversation is productive. The goal is that you walk away confident and prepared to handle tough conversations.

Lea founded LT Coaching, a work and wellness coaching practice. She partners with leaders to ignite radical faith from a place of confidence and peace. Her belief is that everyone is a leader because we all influence the people around us.

She is passionate about creating safe places to not only focus on what we are doing, but who we are being. By caring for ourselves we can then go and care for others well and excel in the fields we are called to work in. She provides tools to live authentically, manage stress and strengthen relationships.

program_name: From Sarah to Sydney: A Conversation with Alexandra Dunietz
program_description:
From Sarah to Sydney by the late June Cummins, is the untold life story of the All-Of-A-Kind Family author Sydney Taylor, highlighting her dramatic influence on American children’s literature. The All-Of-A-Kind Family series, beloved by generations of readers, are the first juvenile novels published by a mainstream publisher to feature Jewish children. The family—based on Taylor’s own as a child—includes five sisters, each two years apart, dressed alike by their fastidious immigrant mother so they all look the same: all-of-a-kind.

Cummins elucidates the deep connections between the progressive Taylor’s books and American Jewish experiences, arguing that Taylor was deeply influential in the development of a national Jewish identity. The biography conveys the vital importance of children’s books in the transmission of Jewish culture and the preservation of ethnic heritage.

Cummins friend and co-author, Alexandra Dunietz, will present followed by a post-lecture Q & A.

June Cummins was professor emerita of English and comparative literature at San Diego State University, where she made important contributions to its National Center for the Study of Children's Literature.

Alexandra Dunietz is a historian of the medieval Middle East.

This program is a collaboration between the Selfhelp Home, the Skokie Public Library, The Village Chicago and the Chicago Public Library.

Program registration includes a 25% discount on the purchase of the book from Yale University Press using discount code YEFSS.

Sphero robots are a great tool for learning some of the basics of computer coding and programming. If you've ever wondered what it's like to write code, drop by the 3rd Floor of the Harold Washington library and get an in person demo of the Sphero Bot in action. The bots roll around, take directional commands, light up, even make animal sounds on command!

In this program attendees will learn to navigate the Sphero bot using the basics of vector programming, also known as "Turtle Graphics." Patrons will also learn about ways to simplify code with the use of loops, and get some experience with step by step computational thinking. The workshop will culminate in navigating the sphero through a maze with various layers of challenge.

This program is designed with a casual "drop-in" style of learning. The instruction start-to-finish should take about 10-15 minutes, and allow patrons some room to experiment and explore the coding aspect in their own way.

No registration required. Just come to the 3rd Floor of the Harold Washington Library Center at noon on October 21.

Learn how to maneuver the mouse and keyboard, the basics of email composition, attachments and organization, learn how to get the most out of your Google search and bring your technology questions!

A happy couple with a lovely country house die in a car accident and must haunt their old home while waiting to be processed into heaven. Too nice to be scary, they befriend the new tenant's daughter. When they fail to prevent the girl's parents from ruining the house, they ask a devilish spirit for help.

program_name: The Value of Community with DePaul University
program_description:
In Bedrock Faith, the 2021 One Book, One Chicago selection, community ties are tested and triumph over questions of faith, fear, and forgiveness. Join DePaul University professors Dr. Rita Mookerjee,  Dr. Megan Alderden and Dan Stolar to listen and ask questions throughout a discussion exploring community’s place in the classroom and across academic pursuits. This diverse discussion aims to bring us together and remind us to appreciate where we come from, and where we’re going.

Dr. Rita Mookerjee is the Ida B. Wells-Barnett Fellow in the African and Black Diaspora Studies Department at DePaul University. Her research areas include contemporary Caribbean literature, gender theory, intersectional feminisms, and food studies. In 2020, she was a Fulbright fellow in Kingston, Jamaica. She is the co-founder of Honey Literary, a BIPOC and queer-centric journal of art and writing, and also serves as the Assistant Poetry Editor at Split Lip Magazine.

Dr. Megan Alderden is an Associate Professor and Director of Criminology at DePaul University. Dr. Alderden has over 20 years of experience conducting criminal justice-related research as well as implementation and outcome evaluations of criminal justice programs. Dr. Alderden’s work includes examining issues within the field of victimology and policing. She worked on two National Institute of Justice funded research studies examining the impact of forensic evidence on police and prosecutorial decisions in sexual assault cases, and was researcher with the National Police Research Platform, where her work focused on police diversification, police culture, and the civilianization of police agencies. She is currently an evaluator of a federally funded reentry program in Chicago and Cook County that focuses on job training and reentry support for individuals post incarceration.

Dan Stolar is the author of a collection of short stories, The Middle of the Night (Picador). His fiction and creative nonfiction have appeared in a numerous publications including, The Virginia Quarterly Review, The Missouri Review, Bomb, the Utne Reader and the Chicago Tribune. He’s an associate professor at DePaul University.

How to Attend:

This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. You'll be able to ask questions during the event as well!
Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

Accessibility

Automatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: DIY: Teen Sugar Skull Making Program
program_description:
Check out this program about the history of the Mexican holiday Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead). This holiday is celebrated in the month of November throughout Mexico and it celebrates the life of loved ones who have passed. Artist Norma Rios-Sierra will teach students how to make sugar skulls.

In this virtual program you will get the chance to learn how to make and decorate your own sugar skull.

Students will learn to make the sugar mixture and frosting, use molds to form the sugar skull and then enjoy personalizing each one.

Pelayo is the author of poetry collections Poems of My Night and Into the Forest and All the Way Through.

Join us throughout the month of October as we get into the spooky spirit of Halloween with movies filled with horror, suspense, and thrills!

Our chilling selection for this week is a double-feature: Halloweentown & Halloweentown II: Kalabar's Revenge.

Halloweentown: Thanks to a visit from Grandmother Aggie, Marnie and her family's tradition of ignoring the Halloween holiday are about to change in the extreme. It seems that Marnie's mother Gwen has been hiding a big secret from her three children--all of them possess supernatural powers.

Halloweentown II: Kalabar's son is bent on revenge. Marnie has matured as a witch, but her powers are pushed to the limit in a desperate effort to triumph over an evil curse in order to save Halloweentown, her family and the human world.

© Walt Disney Pictures - 180 Minutes - Rated G

Emma Stone (LA LA LAND) stars in Disney’s CRUELLA, a live-action feature film about the rebellious early days of one of cinema’s most notorious – and notoriously fashionable – villains, the legendary Cruella de Vil. Set during the 1970s punk rock revolution in London, the story follows a clever and creative young grifter named Estella, who is determined to become a successful designer. After Estella befriends a pair of young thieves who appreciate her appetite for mischief, the three build a life for themselves on the London streets. Before long, Estella’s flair for fashion catches the eye of the Baroness von Hellman, a devastatingly chic and terrifyingly haute fashion legend, played by Emma Thompson (HOWARDS END, SENSE AND SENSIBILITY). But their relationship sets in motion a course of events and revelations that will cause Estella to embrace her wicked side and become the raucous, fashionable and revenge-bent Cruella.

© Walt Disney Pictures-134 Min.-Rated PG

For Latinx Heritage Month, South Chicago Branch will be reading The Alchemist by Paulo Coelho.

Paulo Coelho's enchanting novel has inspired a devoted following around the world. This story, dazzling in its powerful simplicity and soul-stirring wisdom, is about an Andalusian shepherd boy named Santiago who travels from his homeland in Spain to the Egyptian desert in search of a treasure buried near the Pyramids. 

Along the way he meets a Gypsy woman, a man who calls himself king, and an alchemist, all of whom point Santiago in the direction of his quest. No one knows what the treasure is, or if Santiago will be able to surmount the obstacles in his path. But what starts out as a journey to find worldly goods turns into a discovery of the treasure found within. Lush, evocative, and deeply humane, the story of Santiago is an eternal testament to the transforming power of our dreams and the importance of listening to our hearts (Goodreads, 2021).

program_name: Whose Lakefront: Chicago's Unceded Native Land
program_description:
Learn about the history and occupation of Indigenous land by marking the presence of unceded territory in the heart of Chicago’s downtown. The “Whose Lakefront” project is based on a 1914 lawsuit brought by the Pokagon Band of Potawatomi Indians against Chicago for land along the lakefront. Members of the Pokagon Band, based in Michigan, along with a Native resident of Chicago and non-Native ally will discuss this history and contemporary Native sovereignty as highlighted through a recent public art project marking this unceded territory in the heart of Chicago's downtown. Panelists include JeeYeun Lee, John Low, Madolyn Wesaw, and Debra Yepa-Pappan. This program is co-sponsored by CPL’s Native American Heritage Committee.



JeeYeun Lee is an interdisciplinary artist, writer, and activist whose work explores issues of power, connection, and resistance. Her work has been shown in Chicago, Detroit, Santa Fe, Ohio, Missouri, and France. She has worked with social justice and community-based organizations for over thirty years in immigrant rights, economic justice, LGBTQ issues, and domestic violence. She holds an M.F.A. in Fiber from Cranbrook Academy of Art, M.A. in Ethnic Studies from the University of California at Berkeley, and B.A. in Linguistics from Stanford University.



John N. Low Ph.D. is a citizen of the Pokagon Band of Potawatomi and an associate professor at the Ohio State University, where he also serves as Director of the Newark Earthworks Center. John grew up in southwest Michigan and lived for over 15 years in Chicago. He is currently involved in projects with the Field Museum of Natural History, the City of Chicago, the Chicago History Museum, and the MacArthur Foundation.



Madolyn Wesaw is Manager of Tribal Placement and Development at Four Winds Casinos, where she focuses on helping tribal citizens obtain meaningful employment and work towards their professional and educational goals. A citizen of the Pokagon Band of Potawatomi Indians, she also serves Indigenous and other marginalized groups through her work with the American Indian Movement Chapter of Indiana and Kentucky. In addition, she serves on the Interim Coordinating Committee of the Michiana Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression.



Debra Yepa-Pappan (Jemez Pueblo/Korean) is a visual artist with international acclaim in the field of contemporary Native American art, a co-founder of the newly formed Chicago based Center for Native Futures, and the Native Community Engagement Coordinator at the Field Museum, where she welcomes Native American guests to the museum and facilitates their visits to collections. As an active member of the Chicago Native American community, she also serves as a liaison between the museum and the community both locally and nationally. Through her artwork and her work at the Field Museum she is committed to changing inaccurate representations of Native people, and advocates for the inclusion of Native first voice and perspectives. Yepa-Pappan lives in her hometown Chicago with her husband, artist Chris Pappan, and their daughter Ji Hae.

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: The Vanishing Half
program_description:
Join Woodson Regional for a discussion of The Vanishing Half by Brit Bennett. The Vignes twin sisters will always be identical. But after growing up together in a small, southern black community and running away at age sixteen, it's not just the shape of their daily lives that is different as adults, it's everything: their families, their communities, their racial identities. Ten years later, one sister lives with her black daughter in the same southern town she once tried to escape. The other secretly passes for white, and her white husband knows nothing of her past. Still, even separated by so many miles and just as many lies, the fates of the twins remain intertwined. What will happen to the next generation, when their own daughters' storylines intersect?

Copies of the book are available at the Woodson Regional Library Adult Reference Desk.

Join Lala from the Sherman Park Branch for a conversation about how you can include self-care in your daily life.
Self-care is an action or activity that is good for your physical or mental well-being. Pick up your self-care kit at the Sherman Park Branch. Kits are for registered participants. This program is for teens and adults.

Self-care kit includes:

  • Affirmation card and blank cards for your own affirmations
  • Self-care coloring sheets, coloring pencils and sharpener
  • Journal and gel pens
  • Stress ball
  • Tea Bag
  • A list of self-care tips, websites, books and other resources

We will end the program with a short guided-meditation.

Always consult your physician or healthcare provider before starting an exercise program. There is always a risk of injury associated with participating in any type of exercise.

program_name: Research Your Family History with the Polish Genealogical Society of America
program_description:
Curious about your ancestors? Want to map your family tree? Robert Pine, the President of the Polish Genealogical Society of America, will provide a step-by-step introduction to sleuthing out your family background starting here in the US, then how to leap the ocean to research Polish records from home. Learn how to discover who, when, what and where; and how to transform your family tree into family history. All are welcome! This workshop is geared toward folks just getting started in genealogy or anyone looking for a fun refresher.

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May
program_description:
Join Hall Branch for a discussion of Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. 

After 14 years in prison, Gerald "Stew Pot" Reeves returns home to a middle-class African-American neighborhood on Chicago's far South Side. The neighbors are nervous, even though Stew Pot has assured them that he found religion in prison and proclaims himself the moral judge of the neighborhood. Encounters and scandals with residents escalate in intensity until the community is irrevocably changed. Bedrock Faith provides a reflection on God, community, unintended consequences, and the possibilities of finding love without reservation.

How to Attend

program_description:
Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback.

program_name: Adult Reading Circle: The New Jim Crow with Dan Duster
program_description:
Join the Carter G. Woodson Reading Circle as special guest Dan Duster discusses The New Jim Crow by Michelle Alexander.

Dan Duster is a motivational speaker and success coach. Audiences are also inspired by the story of his great-grandmother Ida B. Wells. Duster talks about her struggles and triumphs in the late 1800s to motivate people to overcome obstacles and stand up against injustices that we see today. Born and raised on the South Side of Chicago, Duster has always been a leader.

Author Michelle Alexander describes The New Jim Crow  as a stunning account of the rebirth of a caste-like system in the United States, one that has resulted in millions of African Americans locked behind bars and then relegated to a permanent second-class status—denied the very rights supposedly won in the Civil Rights Movement.

How to Attend

program_name: Neighborhood Tour: The LGBTQ experience in Lakeview and Beyond
program_description:
Over the past years, the LGBTQ experience in Chicago continues to be transformed through various activities, community groups, and individuals. As part of this program, we’ll get a chance to talk with folks at the Center on Halsted, the Legacy Walk and other community groups who continue to define and redefine the conversations around the Lakeview community and beyond.

Join us for virtual neighborhood tours, featuring host and urbanologist Max Grinnell, as we explore the people, places and communities that make Chicago's neighborhoods so special! 

How to Attend:

program_description:
Join Edgewater's preschool story time tailored for you and your proud preschooler! We’ll share songs, rhymes and books, plus suggestions for at-home activities.

For 3- to 5-year-olds and their caregivers.

How to Attend

This event series takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the event. If you are not registered 24 hours before the event, you must wait until the next story time session to attend. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines.

This event uses a third-party website. We recommend you review the privacy policies of any third-party sites before providing them with any personal data. For more information, please see our Website Privacy Statement.

Questions about attending online events? Check out our Events FAQs.

Accessibility

Automatic transcription is included in all CPL events using Zoom. Need live captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4072 or email access@chipublib.org. Requests for live captioning must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

program_name: Grab and Go: PPE Wellness Kit
program_description:
Pick up your Grab and Go PPE (personal protective equipment) wellness kit at Sherman Park Branch. Each bag includes:

  •  Pack of 5 cloth masks
  • 1 pair of vinyl gloves
  • 3 coloring sheets
  • 4 coloring pencils
  • 1 pencil sharpener

Available while supplies last. 

The safety and health of our patrons and staff is our priority. We’re requiring all visitors over age 2 to wear masks that cover nose and mouth. If you do not have a mask, we will provide disposable masks.

When visiting the library, maintain at least six feet of distance from staff and other patrons. Stay home if you or someone in your group are experiencing symptoms of any illness per order of the Chicago Department of Public Health.

Questions about visiting the library? Check out our Using the Library FAQ.

program_name: Feel the Fear: A Horror Roundtable Discussion
program_description:
Get in the Halloween spirit and join a lively discussion with three of today's hottest voices in horror: Stephen Graham Jones, Alma Katsu, and Hailey Piper, moderated by local librarian and Horror expert Becky Spratford. They will talk about why they love Horror, how they bring the fear to life on the page, and what creators they seek out for their own frightening fun. This will be a casual and fun conversation where participation by the audience will be highly encouraged. As a special bonus, the evening will be capped off by the official kick off of the 2022 Summer Scares program with a LIVE announcement of this year's author spokesperson. 

For more information about Summer Scares and for librarian vetted Horror for all ages of readers please visit: http://raforallhorror.blogspot.com/p/summer-scares.html. Come spend a spooky evening with us...if you dare!

How to Attend:

This event will take place on CPL's YouTube channel and Facebook page.
Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

Accessibility

Captioning is available via YouTube's captioning service. Just turn on the captioning option.

Did you attend our RPG 101: Dungeons & Dragons program and are looking for more?  Perhaps you're already familiar with the game, played before but are feeling rusty, or are just looking for some tips on how to improve your game. Join us for our in depth RPG 102: Dungeons & Dragons program focusing on game mechanics, such as character creation, combat, puzzles, and game play scenarios.

If you're altogether new to RPGs (role playing games) or D&D, we suggest you first attend our RPG 101: Dungeons & Dragons program, which offers a holistic introduction to the game, covering the player and Dungeon Master roles, settings, character sheets, dice rolling, and more.

program_name: After High School: FAFSA & Financial Aid
program_description:
How do you picture your life after high school? No idea? Great, because we're here to help you figure it out! After High School is a series of virtual workshops dedicated to assisting teens and their families with post-secondary decisions. So whether that means college, trade schools, jobs, or a plan uniquely designed by you, tune into one of our online sessions for reliable information and advice!

This session will focus on financial aid and the process of completing the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). We will discuss what financial options are available for college, and go through the important steps for filling out the FAFSA. There will also be time given for any questions. 

Before working at the library, your host for this session, Marche, served as a college advisor, guiding over 200 students into their various post-secondary journeys. This included assisting with financial aid, ensuring that students and families were informed before making financial decisions for college. With experience and reliable resources, this presentation will give you tools to come to an informed decision for your finances after high school.

program_name: Advanced Care Planning with Five Wishes
program_description:
One of the greatest gifts you can give your family is to provide guidance on the treatments you would – and would not – want to receive if you were unable to speak for yourself. This is called advance care planning. Sharing this information with your family and loved ones will provide them with peace of mind, while also assuring that your wishes will be honored.

Five Wishes is an easy-to-use legal document that is valid in Illinois and most other states, and is written in everyday language that lets adults plan how they want to be cared for in case they become seriously ill. Five Wishes speaks to a person’s holistic needs: medical, personal, emotional and spiritual.

Presented by Maureen Burns, Community Health Worker, JourneyCare.

How to Attend

program_name: Book Discussion: Drive Your Plow Over the Bones of the Dead
program_description:
Join the Assistive Resources Center Accessible Audiobook Discussion Group for a dial-in phone discussion of Drive your Plow Over the Bones of the Dead by Olga Tokarczuk.

Living in a remote Polish village, Janina has developed a reputation as a crank and recluse. When a neighbor turns up dead and other bodies are discovered in strange circumstances, Janina inserts herself into the investigation.

How to Attend 
This event takes place by phone and especially welcomes patrons with visual disabilities. To register for this event, please call 312-747-4001 for access information. An accessible digital audiobook is available to those who qualify via Illinois State Library Talking Book and Braille Service.

When registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines.

program_name: A Look Back at The Ox-bow Incident
program_description:
The Ox-bow Incident by Walter Van Tilburg Clark was the spring 2005 OBOC selection. This neglected classic western is a powerful novel that grapples with universal questions of justice and morality. Joyce Miller Bean, storyteller, author and former DePaul University English instructor provides a modern take on this timeless work.

How to Attend:

This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. You'll be able to ask questions during the event as well!
Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

Accessibility

Automatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

Junior Maker: Experiments to Try, Crafts to Create, and Lots to Learn!

Join us online for some Halloween-themed science demonstrations and hands-on activities using common, household items! 

For kids 6 to 12.

If you want to follow along at home, here are the supplies we'll be using, but they are not required to join the program:

Dancing Ghosts

  • Balloon
  • White tissue paper (Either craft tissue or regular household tissue will work. White is best for making ghosts but any color will work.)
  • Markers
  • Scissors
  • Tape

Balloon Ghosts

  • White balloon (White is best for ghosts but any color will work)
  • Baking soda
  • Vinegar
  • Empty water bottle
  • Measuring spoons
  • Funnel

Coffee Filter Bat

  • Wooden Spring Clothespins
  • Round White Coffee Filters
  • Assorted Googly Eyes
  • Washable Markers – Black, Blue and Purple
  • Liquid Glue
  • Black Acrylic Craft Paint or Sharpie
  • Paintbrush (if using Craft Paint)
  • Black Cardstock or Construction Paper
  • Scissors
  • White Gel Pen or White Out
  • Pencil
  • Scrap of Cardboard
  • Recommended Tools:
    • Non-Stick Craft Mat or Large Plastic Zip Top Bag
    • Water Spray Bottle

Flying Creatures

  • 11” Balloons (preferably in black or orange but any color will work)
  • Clear Tape
  • Black or Orange Tissue Paper (but any color will work)
  • Clothespins
  • Sharpie Marker

Join Independence Branch for an online discussion of feminist fiction and non-fiction!

Our second title to be discussed will be Roxane Gay's Bad Feminist.  

"This trenchant collection assembles previously published essays and new work by cultural critic and novelist Gay (An Untamed State). Even though she loves pink, feels nostalgic about the Sweet Valley High series, and lets degrading rap lyrics blast from her car stereo, Gay is passionately committed to feminist issues, such as equal opportunity and pay and reproductive freedom. Writing about race, politics, gender, feminism, privilege, and popular media, she highlights how deeply misogyny is embedded in our culture, the careless language used to discuss sexual violence (seen in news reports of sexual assault), Hollywood's tokenistic treatment of race, the trivialization of literature written by women, and the many ways American society fails women and African-Americans. Gay bemoans that fact that role models like Bill Cosby and Don Lemon urge African-Americans to act like ideal citizens while glossing over institutional problems in the education, social welfare, and justice system that exacerbate racism and poverty. Although Gay is aware of her privilege as a middle-class Haitian-American, she doesn't refrain from advising inner-city students to have higher expectations. Whatever her topic, Gay's provocative essays stand out for their bravery, wit, and emotional honesty." ---Publisher's Weekly

program_name: Nostalgia Book Club: Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark
program_description:
When was the last time you revisited one of your favorite books from childhood? This month we will be discussing a scary read - Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark by Alvin Schwartz.  Are the stories as creepy as we remember?  Read the book on your own and let's get together to talk about it.

Stories of ghosts and witches, "jump" stories, scary songs, and modern-day scary stories. Schwartz is best known for the Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark series, which featured gruesome, nightmarish illustrations by Stephen Gammell. The series was America's most frequently challenged book (or book series) for library inclusion of 1990-1999.  --Publisher's description.

You can check out Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark at your favorite Chicago Public Library branch by placing a hold request.
