Join the West Loop Branch for a discussion of Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May 

After fourteen years in prison, Gerald "Stew Pot" Reeves, age thirty-one, returns home to live with his mom in Parkland, a black middle-class neighborhood on Chicago's South Side. A frightening delinquent before being sent away, his return sends Parkland residents into a religiously infused tailspin, which only increases when Stew Pot announces that he experienced a religious awakening in prison. Through the unforgettable characters of Stew Pot and Mrs. Motley, the novel provides a reflection on God, the living and the dead, and the possibilities of finding love without reservation.

A limited number of copies are located behind the circulation desk at the West Loop Branch.

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Just As I Am by Cicely Tyson
program_description:
Join Pullman Branch Library for a discussion of Cicely Tyson's memoir, Just as I Am.

"Just As I Am is my truth. It is me, plain and unvarnished, with the glitter and garland set aside. In these pages, I am indeed Cicely, the actress who has been blessed to grace the stage and screen for six decades. Yet I am also the church girl who once rarely spoke a word. I am the teenager who sought solace in the verses of the old hymn for which this book is named. I am a daughter and mother, a sister, and a friend. I am an observer of human nature and the dreamer of audacious dreams. I am a woman who has hurt as immeasurably as I have loved, a child of God divinely guided by His hand. And here in my ninth decade, I am a woman who, at long last, has something meaningful to say."

program_name: Paint Your Story: Your Voice on Canvas
program_description:
Polish artist Patricia Stepniak uses mixed media and Polish folk tales to inspire kids to create their own picture stories using watercolors, oil pastels, ink and scrapbooking materials. All supplies provided!

A graduate of the Fine Arts School in Poland, Patricia Stepniak’s whole life is centered around sharing her artistic talents with the world. Patricia is well versed in many different areas of the fine arts, including painting, designing and sculpting among others. She teaches, creates art and uses her knowledge to train the next generation of artists at her own studio – PatriciaARTStudio.

This event is sponsored by the Polish American Services Committee in celebration of Polish American Heritage Month.

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Mapping the Interior
program_description:
All are welcome to join a book discussion of Mapping the Interior by Stephen Graham Jones.

“Blackfeet author Stephen Graham Jones brings readers a spine-tingling Native American horror novella.

Walking through his own house at night, a fifteen-year-old thinks he sees another person stepping through a doorway. Instead of the people who could be there, his mother or his brother, the figure reminds him of his long-gone father, who died mysteriously before his family left the reservation. When he follows it, he discovers his house is bigger and deeper than he knew.

The house is the kind of wrong place where you can lose yourself and find things you'd rather not have. Over the course of a few nights, the boy tries to map out his house in an effort that puts his little brother in the worst danger, and puts him in the position to save them . . . at terrible cost.” - from the publisher, Tor.com

program_name: Hospice 101: Understanding Hospice Care & Its Benefits
program_description:
Hospice care is one of the most unique and robust types of care covered under Medicare. However, many people don’t know much about this type of care. This workshop will describe in detail what hospice is, who is eligible, who pays for care, and what services are included. We will also discuss common misconceptions about hospice care and how lived experiences influence people’s care decisions. Learn all that hospice has to offer and how it can look different for each individual. Presented by Maureen Burns, Rogers Park Area Community Health Worker at JourneyCare.

Angela Seals is an award-nominee indie author and Chicago native with an awesome imagination for storytelling. She currently works as a senior accountant by day and a writer by night. Her novels offer real life issues and compelling love affairs and speak to her readers desire to find love by providing life, imagery, and words to their thoughts and fantasies. These dynamic stories derived from her love of reading, which began in her early teens. Angela pens contemporary romance and women fiction. However, out of her love for all genres grew her alter-ego Angel de’Amor. Manifested from the edgy characters floating around in her head that could not be contained, Angel de’Amar was born to dominate her love for her fiery women fiction stories. Angela continues to write under both names to offer her readers a variety of stories filled with temptation and forbidden love affairs. Angela loves connecting with her readers and you can find her curled up reading a book or working on her next dynamic, sultry story. Additionally, Angela will discuss her current release The Royal Mess (Modern Day Socialite Book One) and future projects with the readers. Copies of this title will be available at Walker Branch

Hopelessly Forever

This month, we're reading Mexican Gothic by Silvia Moreno-Garcia.

After receiving a frantic letter from her newly-wed cousin begging for someone to save her from a mysterious doom, Noemí Taboada heads to High Place, a distant house in the Mexican countryside. She’s not sure what she will find—her cousin’s husband, a handsome Englishman, is a stranger, and Noemí knows little about the region.

Noemí is also an unlikely rescuer: She’s a glamorous debutante, and her chic gowns and perfect red lipstick are more suited for cocktail parties than amateur sleuthing. But she’s also tough and smart, with an indomitable will, and she is not afraid: Not of her cousin’s new husband, who is both menacing and alluring; not of his father, the ancient patriarch who seems to be fascinated by Noemí; and not even of the house itself, which begins to invade Noemí’s dreams with visions of blood and doom. (Goodreads, 2021).

program_name: The Neighborhood Notebook with I Am Adverb
program_description:
The Neighborhood Notebook provides fun and engaging writing activities that build community and develop writing skills. Over the course of the workshops, you will read a prompt, submit an entry/response, and share their writing, developing a Neighborhood Notebook of poems and culminating in a reading. I Am Adverb is a board member of Abj Millennial Tribe, a spoken word artist, program instructor and team lead of Original Men In Black. 

This is being presented as a three part series, and you should plan to attend all three workshops. 

This event is co-sponsored by CPL’s Poetry Committee.

program_name: DACA 101: Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals
program_description:
Chicago Law and Education Foundation is pleased to present DACA 101. Learn more about the program, what it does and doesn't do in this informational seminar. Discussion will include DACA's history and where it stands right now, and detail some of the impact the program has already had. Will discuss eligibility to apply for DACA, what the requirements are, and what applicants need to prove they meet them. We'll talk about where to obtain documents and evidence and run through some hypothetical scenarios. Finally, we'll answer any questions and let attendees know how they can contact us to start the application process. 

How to Attend:

program_name: Adult Writing and Poetry- A Writer's Thoughts
program_description:
You got a story to tell, a book to write, and your thoughts are just all over the place, well let’s come together and get those thoughts onto paper.

A Writer’s Thoughts is a 45 minute program series designed to help writers to get their thoughts organized and on paper making it easier for authors to tell their story.

Meet every other Tuesday from 5pm-5:45pm via zoom.

program_name: Learning Circle: The Art of Storytelling with Pixar
program_description:
Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. 

This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required. 

Please register for Virtual Learning Circle The Art of Storytelling with Pixar on the P2PU website for this learning course.

program_name: The Ribbon Skirts of Agnes Woodward
program_description:
Join us for a talk about Native/Indigenous ribbon skirts and sisterhood with Agnes Woodward. 

AgnesWoodward is Plains Cree from Kawacatoose First Nations, Saskatchewan, Canada. Shehas lived in North Dakota with her husband and children for the last sixteen years.

Agnesis an MMIWG2S family member and advocate, an activist, Speaker, grassroots community organizer, and co-owner of ReeCreeations. Agnesis a proud ribbon skirt maker who uses applique art as a way to tell stories, empower Indigenous people, bring healing, visibility and connection to Indigenous identity.

How to Attend

Can't make it to the live stream? We will archive the video to watch later.

Accessibility
Captioning can be turned on by the user on both YouTube and Facebook.

program_name: Neighborhood Tour: The Communion Around Beverages
program_description:
In Bedrock Faith, people gather. Some people gather around martinis. Other people gather around beer. And still others gather around other beverages. This guided tour through Chicago will talk about why Windy City residents of legal age gather around in lounges, taverns, and other places for cold libations and conversation with others. It will be a spirited conversation.

Join us for virtual neighborhood tours, featuring host and urbanologist Max Grinnell, as we explore the people, places and communities that make Chicago's neighborhoods so special!

program_name: Rapbrary Book Discussion: Decoded by Jay Z
program_description:
Join CPL and the Richard M. Daley Branch as we read and discuss Decoded by Jay Z and enjoy renditions of his greatest hits from violinist Edith Yokley of the Chicago Sinfonietta's Resident Orchestra Project. We commemorate the 18th anniversary of Jay Z's the Black Album, and the 10 year anniversary of Decoded by Jay Z; a compelling work, that makes the case that Hip Hop lyrics are poetry. 

"Decoded is the autobiography and memoir of rapper Jay-Z, published by Random House and released November 16, 2010 on hardcover and November 1, 2011 on paperback. The book combines lyrics, their explanations, anecdotes, reflections, and autobiographical information. Jay-Z explains the three reasons why he wanted to write the book being a case for hip-hop lyrics as poetry, to tell a generational story turned into powerful experiences and revolved as a story everyone can relate to."

program_name: David Sadowski on Chicago’s Lost Ls
program_description:
Chicago’s system of elevated railways, known locally as the “L,” has run continuously since 1892 and, like the city, has never stood still. It helped neighborhoods grow, brought their increasingly diverse populations together, and gave the famous Loop its name. But today’s system has changed radically over the years. Chicago's Lost "L"s tells the story of former lines such as Garfield Park, Humboldt Park, Kenwood, Stockyards, Normal Park, Westchester, and Niles Center. It was once possible to take high-speed trains on the L directly to Aurora, Elgin, and Milwaukee, Wisconsin. The L started out as four different companies, two starting out using steam engines instead of electricity. Eventually, all four came together via the Union Loop. The L is more than a way of getting around. Its trains are a place where people meet and interact. Some say the best way to experience the city is via the L, with its second-story view. Chicago’s Lost “L”s is virtually a “secret history” of Chicago, and this is your ticket.

Author David Sadowski grew up riding the L all over the city. He is the author of Chicago Trolleys and Building Chicago's Subways and runs the online Trolley Dodger blog.

How to Attend:
This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. You'll be able to ask questions during the event as well! Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

program_name: Kartemquin Films Presents 2021 Empowering Truth Benefit
program_description:
Chicago Public Library and Kartemquin Films have collaborated on several exciting projects over the past years. Kartemquin Films is thrilled to be hosting their third annual Empowering Truth Benefit celebrating the 55-year legacy of Kartemquin Films as Chicago’s documentary powerhouse. They have put together an amazing virtual line up to celebrate their past, present and future as a leading advocate for independent nonfiction media.

Celebrating the voices and work of KTQ filmmakers and drawing on their rich history, the Empowering Truth Benefit will engage themes of equity and representation in the media field through a series of dynamic conversations.

To learn more about this event and to register, please visit Kartemquin's Empowering Truth Benefit. 

We encourage you to attend this free virtual event!

program_description:

"When a dying millionaire hires Philip Marlowe to handle the blackmailer of one of his two troublesome daughters, Marlowe finds himself involved with more than extortion. program_name: The Art of Storytelling: Hybrid Virtual and In-Person Learning Circle
program_description:
THE ART OF STORYTELLING LEARNING CIRCLE

How would you tell the story of your community? Strengthen your storytelling skills with a learning circle this fall!

Do you know you can take an online course at the library in a learning circle? A learning circle is a study group for learners who want to complete online courses, together with others. This is a free opportunity for adults to learn new skills with others.  Learning Circles are presented as multi-week courses, and you should plan to attend each of the classes.

Join a five part course focused on the art of telling your story. You’ll join with others to learn the tools of the storytelling trade and write your own original story or poems! We will cover a new topic each week, focusing on story structure, point-of-view, characterization, description, and style. 

This course will take place virtually and in person. Capacity is limited. Registration is required and COVID-19 safety protocols will be followed for in-person attendance. If taking this learning circle virtually, you will need free Zoom software.

Accessibility
Need captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 10 business days before the event.

This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Feng Shui: Take Command of your Life
program_description:
When you put yourself in "Command" of your life, your life improves, situations shift, and many new opportunities may show up in unexpected ways. Learn how to position yourself for the best possibilities to come your way using the time tested guidelines of Feng Shui. Laurie Pawli will share information on exactly how to incorporate these methods into your space for your benefit.

Laurie is a student of Grand Master Professor Lin Yun with her Feng Shui Certification from The Integrative School of Feng Shui in San Diego, CA. She studied design at Northern Illinois University and worked at Chicago’s Merchandise Mart.

program_name: 1993, Another Summer, Sound of Chicago’s Funky Drummer
program_description:
What was Chicago like in 1993? Utilizing Chicago Tribune articles, author and urbanologist Max Grinnell looks into news stories about Cabrini Green, the new Comiskey Park, public schools, and other matters to talk about the cultural and social milieu around the city. Along the way, we'll also check in at the Chicago Bulls 1993 championship rally, listen to some local radio legends Eddie & JoBo, and hear about Moo & Oink's meat products.

As an urbanologist, geographer, historian, and professor, Max Grinnell finds his purpose in describing, critiquing, and analyzing the urban condition. He’s an expert on urban design, planning, public art, the creative economy, and the history of cities, and has written several books including Hyde Park, Illinois and 24 Great Walks in Chicago. 

How to Attend:
This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

Accessibility
Automatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

program_name: Adult Crafting: Learn Origami with Esteban
program_description:
Join the North Pulaski Branch and our neighborhood origami man, Esteban, to learn origami basics. Esteban will lead us through everything from the beginner's crane to more medium/intermediate animals and even some Halloween inspired origami.

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: The Feather Thief
program_description:
Join us as we discuss The Feather Thief by Kirk Wallace Johnson. The Feather Thief recounts the enthralling story of a young, gifted musician who robbed the British Museum at Tring of more than a million dollars' worth of rare bird specimens for their beautiful feathers, coveted by fly tiers like himself. In the late 18th and 19th centuries, there was considerable demand for bird feathers, particularly from exotic birds, for fashion. The feathers are also in demand among fly tiers, which is how Rist, a young American studying music at the Royal Academy of Music and one of the best fly tiers in the world, was compelled to rob the museum. Johnson chases down priceless specimens that were sold by Rist and interviews Rist himself to dive deeper into the obsessive and strange world of fly tiers.

Copies of this month's selection will be available 30 days prior to the event at the 6th floor reference desk at Harold Washington Library Center (400 South State Street, Chicago IL, 60605).

program_name: Know Your Rights with Cabrini Green Legal Aid
program_description:
Have you ever wondered - What exactly is a criminal record? Whether you have to say “yes” if an employer asks if you have ever been arrested? What is the difference between sealing and expungement? If you are eligible to expunge or seal your record? Cabrini Green Legal Aid representatives will present a workshop to answer all these questions and more.

She teaches bookbinding, printmaking and embroidery classes at Evanston Art Center, Lillstreet Art Center, and co-curates at Parlour and Ramp Gallery in the Pilsen Neighborhood of Chicago.

program_name: The Neighborhood Notebook with I Am Adverb
program_description:
The Neighborhood Notebook provides fun and engaging writing activities that build community and develop writing skills. Over the course of the workshops, you will read a prompt, submit an entry/response, and share their writing, developing a Neighborhood Notebook of poems and culminating in a reading. Included are images of some of Uptown’s more well-known landmarks as well as less famous locations that played important roles in the daily lives of community members.

Tune in for a special series of videos featuring archival material related to Chicago’s neighborhoods. CPL archivists and librarians showcase secrets and treasures from the archives that highlight our city’s history.

program_name: Obtención de su Tarjeta Verde: Sesión de Información sobre el Ajuste del Estado
program_description:
La Biblioteca Pública de Harold Washington está organizando una presentación virtual en PowerPoint sobre "How to Get Your Green Card” (cómo obtener su residencia legal permanente). María del Carmen Rodríguez, Oficial de Relaciones comunitarias del USCIS, realizará una visión general del proceso de adaptación a la residencia legal permanente (LPR). Oficial Rodríguez discutirá las categorías de visa, el proceso de entrada en los Estados Unidos, y los requisitos de elegibilidad para aquellos que buscan el estatus LPR. La discusión incluirá una descripción de los muchos tipos de visas disponibles—tanto no inmigrantes como inmigrantes, y los tipos de ajustes de LPR—basados en la familia y el empleo. Al final de la presentación habrá una oportunidad para hacer preguntas.

Cómo asistir:

Este evento tiene lugar en Zoom. Regístrese antes de las 10 a.m. del día anterior al evento. Recibirá un correo electrónico con un enlace a la reunión segura de Zoom aproximadamente 24 horas antes de la reunión. Al registrarse para este evento, acepta cumplir con las Pautas de uso de la biblioteca.

Accesibilidad
Accesibilidad de transcripción automático está incluido en todos los eventos de CPL usando Zoom. Necesita subtitulado en vivo para el evento. Por favor llame al (312) 747-4072 o mande un correo electrónico a: access@chicago.org. Las solicitudes para subtitulados en vivo se deben hacer por lo menos 14 días laborales antes del evento.

DACA protects young people, who came to the United States as children, from deportation, and provides for work authorization, advance parole and better life opportunities. Presenters will address the history & current status of DACA, as well as eligibility for initial & renewal applications. The presentation will be followed by Q&A.

Please note, this event will take place in Spanish.

program_name: Hospice 101: Understanding Hospice Care and its Benefits
program_description:
Hospice care is one of the most unique and robust types of care covered under Medicare. However, many people don’t know much about this type of care. This workshop will describe in detail, what hospice is, who is eligible, who pays for care, and what services are included. We will also discuss common misconceptions about hospice care and how lived experiences influence people’s care decisions. Learn all that hospice has to offer and how it can look different for each individual.

Presented by: Maureen Burns, Rogers Park Area Community Health Worker at JourneyCare.

program_name: Walking in Two Worlds: Growing up Indigenous in Turtle Island
program_description:
Madolyn Wesaw

Activist Madolyn Wesaw discusses the complexities of growing up Indigenous in modern America. From erasure in educational systems to misrepresentation in pop culture, learn what we can do to create a more inclusive future for native youth.

Madolyn Wesaw is an indigenous activist and mother. A citizen of the Pokagon Band of Potawatomi Indians, she serves Indigenous and other marginalized groups through her work with the American Indian Movement Chapter of Indiana and Kentucky. In addition, Madolyn serves on the Interim Coordinating Committee of the Michiana Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression. She has been involved in projects with the Civil Rights Heritage Center in South Bend, IN., The Kroc Institute for International Peace Studies, and the Newberry Library.

program_name: Neighborhood Tour: A Diverse Business Landscape, Chicago Style
program_description:
What makes a great neighborhood? What makes a great retail environment? Most people would probably say that they would like to patronize a diverse set of businesses as they make their way around Chicago. On this tour, we’ll hear from some different business owners about their own challenges and opportunities, along with talking a bit about the history of these businesses.

Join us for virtual neighborhood tours, featuring host and urbanologist Max Grinnell, as we explore the people, places and communities that make Chicago's neighborhoods so special!

program_description:

ICNC is a partner of The Hatchery Chicago. Together they will be offering a culinary training program for young adults. ICNC works with start-ups and established businesses in industries such as manufacturing, food/beverage, apparel/textiles, and more.

program_name: Rapbrary Book Discussion: Decoded by Jay Z
program_description:
Join CPL and the Richard M. Daley Branch as we read and discuss Decoded by Jay Z and enjoy renditions of his greatest hits from violinist Edith Yokley of the Chicago Sinfonietta's Resident Orchestra Project. We commemorate the 18th anniversary of Jay Z's the Black Album, and the 10 year anniversary of Decoded by Jay Z; a compelling work, that makes the case that Hip Hop lyrics are poetry. 

"Decoded is the autobiography and memoir of rapper Jay-Z, published by Random House and released November 16, 2010 on hardcover and November 1, 2011 on paperback. The book combines lyrics, their explanations, anecdotes, reflections, and autobiographical information. Jay-Z explains the three reasons why he wanted to write the book being a case for hip-hop lyrics as poetry, to tell a generational story turned into powerful experiences and revolved as a story everyone can relate to."

program_name: Betty Crocker and Her Cookbook That Changed How America Cooks with Leslie Goddard
program_description:
Long before Martha Stewart, there was Betty Crocker. In 1950, her brand-new picture cookbook hit the shelves. To date, it has sold more than 75 million copies. Created in 1921 by a flour company, Betty Crocker became the most famous and most trusted advisor to American cooks. This fun illustrated lecture by historian Leslie Goddard, Ph.D. and hosted by Edgebrook Branch, looks at how Betty Crocker was invented, why her cookbook has endured and what makes her so iconic. It’s perfect if you’re feeling like cooking up some nostalgia.

Tune in for an interview with multimedia organizer Johnnie Jae and learn more about how Native/Indigenous creators are breaking through and creating their own multimedia platforms to tell their stories. 

Johnnie Jae is an Otoe-Missouria and Choctaw rabble-rousing journalist, organizer, creator, and futurist who loves empowering others to chase their passions and create for healing and revolutionary change in the world. She is the founder of A Tribe Called Geek, an award-winning media platform for Indigenous Geek Culture and STEM, and #Indigenerds4Hope, a suicide prevention initiative designed to educate, encourage, and empower Native youth. Jae is a co-founder of Not Your Mascots and LiveIndigenousOK. She is a member of the Women Warriors Work Collective and served as a co-chair for the March for Racial Justice. She leads numerous workshops that address Mental Health and Suicide in Indian Country, Native Mascots & Stereotypes, Indigenous Representation & Journalism, Indigenous STEM & Tech, and the Utilization of Social & Digital media for Business and Activism. Her ability to seamlessly shift from humor and pop culture to advocacy and business has made her a much-sought after speaker, panelist, and commentator.

How to Attend
This event will take place on CPL's YouTube channel and Facebook channels.

Can't make it to the live stream? We will archive the video to watch later.

Accessibility
Captioning can be turned on by the user on both YouTube and Facebook.

program_name: Art of Asemic Drawing with Kaye Buchman
program_description:
Students in this workshop will explore the art of asemic drawing, a creative form of expressive mark making derived from handwriting, cursive writing, and calligraphy.  Using commercial ink pens and color pencils, we will experiment with a variety of asemic drawing methods including angular, looping, and freeform styles.  Afterwards, we will add color to create patterns and subjects of interest.  The workshop is open to students of all levels and no prior drawing experience required. Drawing materials will be provided.

program_name: The Art of Storytelling: Hybrid Virtual and In-Person Learning Circle
program_description:
THE ART OF STORYTELLING LEARNING CIRCLE

How would you tell the story of your community? Strengthen your storytelling skills with a learning circle this fall!

Do you know you can take an online course at the library in a learning circle? A learning circle is a study group for learners who want to complete online courses, together with others. This is a free opportunity for adults to learn new skills with others.  Learning Circles are presented as multi-week courses, and you should plan to attend each of the classes.

Join a five part course focused on the art of telling your story. You’ll join with others to learn the tools of the storytelling trade and write your own original story or poems! We will cover a new topic each week, focusing on story structure, point-of-view, characterization, description, and style. 

This course will take place virtually and in person. Capacity is limited. Registration is required and COVID-19 safety protocols will be followed for in-person attendance. If taking this learning circle virtually, you will need free Zoom software.

program_name: Urban Book Discussion: Dirty Little Secrets
program_description:
Please join Legler Regional staff as we discuss Dirty Little Secrets By Joy King.

"Nothing prepares Tyler Blake for the fast-paced living of New York City. A small-town girl from Georgia, she quickly gets caught up in the glamorous entertainment industry. While pursuing her dream of becoming an actress, Tyler continually gets sidetracked by men who promise to help her and finds herself going from one dysfunctional relationship to another. Just when Tyler finally believes she has found her ideal man, in hip-hop producer Brian McCall, everything begins to go horribly wrong. Trapped in a nightmarish relationship, Tyler is determined not to go down without a fight."

program_name: The Quiet Year – Community Storytelling and Mapmaking Game
program_description:
Using gameplay as a means of building community, join the library as we explore and play the critically acclaimed storytelling and cartography game The Quiet Year by designer Avery Alder.

The Quiet Year is a unique game built around map making and community life after a devastating event. Players will use a deck of cards that correspond to weeks of the year, with each card representing one week. Each week brings questions and decisions driven by luck, omens, and other elements that affect everyone and everything in the fictional community being built. Each of these elements are then added to a map which takes shape over the course of the year. By the end of the game, players will have collaboratively told the story one year of community life and represented it on a shared map. No need for roleplaying game experience to join, though this program is aimed towards teen and adult audiences.


How to Attend:

This game will take place virtually. You will need to download free Zoom software. Advance registration is required.

program_name: Citywide Special Event: Wellness for Beginners
program_description:

For parents and caregivers.

Children and families of all kinds are welcome to attend as well.

Always consult your physician or healthcare provider before starting an exercise program. There is always a risk of injury associated with participating in any type of exercise.

Debra Yepa-Pappan

Join us for a talk with visual artist Debra Yepa-Pappan (Jemez Pueblo/ Korean) whose digital works center on themes about her mixed-race identity. She is also the Community Engagement Coordinator for the Native American Exhibition renovation at the Field Museum. Debra discusses how through her artwork and her work at the Museum, she is committed to changing inaccurate representations of Native people and advocates for the inclusion of Native first voice and perspectives.

Debra has international acclaim in the field of contemporary Native American art. She is co-founder of the newly formed Chicago based Center for Native Futures and as the Native Community Engagement Coordinator, she welcomes Native American guests to the Field Museum and facilitates their visits to collections. As an active member of the Chicago Native American community, she also serves as a liaison between the museum and the community both locally and nationally. Debra lives in her hometown Chicago with her husband, artist Chris Pappan, and their daughter Ji Hae.

How to Attend
This event takes place on Zoom. Please register at least 24 hours before the event begins. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines.

program_name: Neighborhood Tour: Make A Joyful Sound - Chicago Plays and Plays and Plays and Sings and Plays
program_description:
Music animates all corners of Chicago and the city’s beats and rhythms can be found in Jackson Park, the Green Mill, Symphony Center, and up and down Michigan Avenue. It’s been a tough time for live music as of late, of course. With that in mind, we’ll head out to talk to Chicagoans and others around the Loop to talk about how they’ve still made music a part of their lives during these times. And hey—we’re also going to hear music from Millennium Park!

Join us for virtual neighborhood tours, featuring host and urbanologist Max Grinnell, as we explore the people, places and communities that make Chicago's neighborhoods so special! 


How to Attend:

This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

Accessibility

Automatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: This Tender Land
program_description:
Join the staff of the Beverly Branch for a discussion of This Tender Land by William K. Krueger. 

This Tender Land tells the story of four orphans who flee a boarding school where hundreds of Native American children are forcibly separated from their parents. Set in Minnesota during the Great Depression of 1932, the orphans cross paths with a variety of people on their epic quest to find a home of their own.

Woodson Regional Library is partnering with SHARE Network of the University of Chicago Biological Sciences by providing resources for older adults on the South Side. This support group is open for individuals who serve as caregivers for individuals with dementia. The support group will entail discussions on topics that are inspired by the interest and needs of the participating dementia-caregivers, such as daily care activities related to food and eating, communication, safety, behavior, and aggression, just to name a few.

Research shows that there are too few geriatric specialists to meet the current needs of older South Side residents. The Woodson Dementia-Caregivers Support Group is designed to provide additional support for South Side residents. "Caregiver Stress Reductions Tool Kits" will be available for all participants of this session. Details for obtaining the kits will be provided in the session.

Presented by Jenil Bennett, a geriatrics community health worker and Monica Long, a clinical research nurse educator, both from SHARE Network at University of Chicago.

program_name: Rapbrary Book Discussion: Decoded by Jay Z
program_description:
Join CPL and the Richard M. Daley Branch as we read and discuss Decoded by Jay Z and enjoy renditions of his greatest hits from violinist Edith Yokley of the Chicago Sinfonietta's Resident Orchestra Project. We commemorate the 18th anniversary of Jay Z's the Black Album, and the 10 year anniversary of Decoded by Jay Z; a compelling work, that makes the case that Hip Hop lyrics are poetry. 

"Decoded is the autobiography and memoir of rapper Jay-Z, published by Random House and released November 16, 2010 on hardcover and November 1, 2011 on paperback. The book combines lyrics, their explanations, anecdotes, reflections, and autobiographical information. Jay-Z explains the three reasons why he wanted to write the book being a case for hip-hop lyrics as poetry, to tell a generational story turned into powerful experiences and revolved as a story everyone can relate to."

program_name: Make and Care Drop-In Studio with ArtWorks
program_description:
Join us the first three Wednesdays of every month to engage in self and collective care through arts and crafts making. This is an opportunity to commit time to your art/craft practice, meet new people, and support one another for the sake of mutual care and wellbeing.

At the virtual drop-in studio, you can use any arts or crafts materials you have on hand to make whatever you’d like, though there will be a weekly theme at the ready if you need some inspiration. Come learn from and share art/craft skills or creative tips with other participants and enjoy a supportive arts environment for makers of all skill levels.

program_name: The Art of Storytelling: Hybrid Virtual and In-Person Learning Circle
program_description:
THE ART OF STORYTELLING LEARNING CIRCLE

How would you tell the story of your community? Strengthen your storytelling skills with a learning circle this fall!

Do you know you can take an online course at the library in a learning circle? A learning circle is a study group for learners who want to complete online courses, together with others. This is a free opportunity for adults to learn new skills with others.  Learning Circles are presented as multi-week courses, and you should plan to attend each of the classes.

Join a five part course focused on the art of telling your story. You’ll join with others to learn the tools of the storytelling trade and write your own original story or poems! We will cover a new topic each week, focusing on story structure, point-of-view, characterization, description, and style. 

This course will take place virtually and in person. Capacity is limited. Registration is required and COVID-19 safety protocols will be followed for in-person attendance. If taking this learning circle virtually, you will need free Zoom software.

Accessibility
Need captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 10 business days before the event.

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: A Rain of Night Birds
program_description:
Join Legler Regional Library in celebrating Native American Heritage Month as we discuss A Rain of Night Birds 
by Deena Metzger. We will also learn about the library's historic mural “Wilderness, Winter River Scene” by Midwestern artist R. Fayerweather Babcock.

Perhaps never before in the history of humankind has the disparity between Indigenous mind and Western mind been more on the pulse of what we must pay attention to in order to insure our survival. Deena Metzger has written a novel in which two people, who are from each side of this polarity, begin a loving relationship. Sandra Birdswell is a student of climatology with an uncanny ability to sense weather events. She first meets Terrence, a Native man and a professor of climatology, at her university classes. Years later, they are drawn together by the powerful forces of their love, for the Earth, for each other, and their mutual need to seek out the broken links of their family histories.

program_name: Author Chat and Adult Book Discussion: The Aftermath by Iris Bolling
program_description:
Join the Brainerd Branch for a conversation with acclaimed African American author Iris Bolling as she discusses her latest release The Aftermath: A Nate Reigns Novel and other future projects with readers. Her latest novel is sure to take you on a wild ride of mystery and suspense. 

Major Crimes Division detective and one-time top criminal defense attorney, Nathan ‘Nate’ Reigns, uses his insight from his previous occupation to close his cases. His friend and mentor, Prosecuting Attorney Alex Burnett, is found dead. His death investigation ensues. The investigation leads to the discovery of other crimes which garners huge headlines for the Richmond Police Department. For the brass, the number of closed cases is a triumph, however, it does not solve the murder of Nate's friend. Nate vows justice.   

This suspense thriller with a twist is sure to leave you gasping to breathe…The innocent and the guilty have to deal with the Aftermath.

How to Get a Copy of the Book: 
You can find an electronic copy of the title on the author's website or most other online outlets where books are sold.

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Before We Were Yours
program_description:
The Literature & Language Book Club will discuss Before We Were Yours by Lisa Wingate. On a stormy night in 1930s Tennessee, the five Rill children are abducted from their poor but happy life on a Mississippi River shanty-boat while their mother is away giving birth to their newest sibling. They are taken to the Tennessee Children’s Home Society Orphanage where they are treated abusively until they are sold to wealthy, childless couples. Rill Foss is only 12 years old when she is stolen, and this is the tale of her lifelong quest to reunite her siblings. This story is based on a real life orphanage run by the notorious Georgia Tann from the 1920s to the 1950s. Readers who love real life scandals will be fascinated by this story which mixes fact with fiction.

How to Attend
Copies of this month's selection will be available 30 days prior to the event at the 7th floor Literature and Language reference desk at Harold Washington Library Center (400 South State Street, Chicago IL, 60605). This event takes place on Zoom. Register by 12:00 p.m. on Thursday, November 18. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Lady in the Lake
program_description:
Join the Budlong Woods Branch for a discussion of Lady in the Lake by Laura Lippman.

The New York Times bestselling author returns with a novel set in 1960s Baltimore that combines modern psychological insights with elements of classic noir. In 1966, Baltimore is a city of secrets that everyone seems to know--everyone, that is, except Madeline "Maddie" Schwartz. Last year, she was a happy, even pampered housewife. This year, she's bolted from her marriage of almost twenty years, determined to make good on her youthful ambitions to live a passionate, meaningful life. Maddie wants to matter, to leave her mark on a swiftly changing world. Drawing on her own secrets, she helps Baltimore police find a murdered girl--assistance that leads to a job at the city's afternoon newspaper, the Star. Working at the newspaper offers Maddie the opportunity to make her name, and she has found just the story to do it: a missing black woman whose body was discovered in the fountain of a city park lake. --Publisher

program_name: Anne Shimojima's Sakura Tales; Stories from Japan
program_description:
Anne Shimojima, a third generation Japanese American, has been sharing traditional Japanese folk tales for over thirty years. We invite you to listen to eleven of these - Sakura Tales; Stories from Japan - in an hour long program for teens and adults hosted by the Asian American and Pacific Islander Committee. Sakura is the Japanese word for cherry blossom.

Folk tales are often forgotten as we grow older. Revisiting and remembering them is a gateway to novel and more enriching experiences and is a beautiful way to commemorate and rekindle the past. By telling the Sakura Tales, Shimojima can feel the connection to her great-grandparents' silkworm farm in Nagano-ken, and she honors the memory of her immigrant grandparents, whose spirit of gaman (perseverance) helped them survive life in a new land. 

Anne became a professional storyteller in 1982. She taught graduate courses in storytelling for National-Louis University and for eight years served on the board of the Wild Onion Storytelling Festival in Chicago. She is a member of the National Storytelling Network, the Northlands Storytelling Network, and Illinois Storytelling, Inc.

program_name: Adult Book Club: We Were the Lucky Ones
program_description:
Join the Merlo Branch Adult Book Club for a discussion of We Were the Lucky Ones by Georgia Hunter.

"It is the spring of 1939, and three generations of the Kurc family are doing their best to live normal lives, even as the shadow of war grows ever closer. The talk around the family Seder table is of new babies and budding romance, not of the increasing hardships facing Jews in their hometown of Radom, Poland. But soon the horrors overtaking Europe will become inescapable and the Kurc family will be flung to the far corners of the earth, each desperately trying to chart his or her own path toward safety."

program_name: Film Discussion: The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson (2017)
program_description:
This month, please watch the documentary The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson, then join us for a discussion. 

The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson | Official Trailer [HD] | Netflix


Watch The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson on Netflix: https://www.netflix.com/title/...

David France’s The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson is a deeply compelling look at the murder of a transgender legend, known as “the Rosa Parks of the LGBT movement.” The powerful, haunting film is France’s follow-up to his Academy Award® nominated How to Survive a Plague.

Public Square Films present the Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson; Joy A. Tomchin and Sara Ramirez (Grey’s Anatomy) served as executive producers; L.A. Teodosio produced.

U.S. Rating: TV-MA For mature audiences. It may not be suitable for ages 17 and under.

Please watch the film in advance of the program.

program_name: Born in Humboldt Park Poetry Workshop & Open Mic with Eduardo Arocho
program_description:
Acclaimed poet and lifelong Humboldt Park resident Eduardo Arocho will teach a short writing workshop that will help participants translate their unique cultural heritage into poetry. 

Eduardo Arocho is a poet and the publisher of Bobbin Lace Press launched in 2017. He is the author of six chapbooks of poetry and his poems have appeared in We Are by The Chicago Community Trust, Cantalogia I: El Amor (Palabra Pura Poets) by Pandora Lobo Estepario Press, Chicago, El CENTRO JOURNAL, Center for Puerto Rican Studies at Hunter College, New York, NY, Power Lines: Anthology by Tia Chucha Press, and Open Fist: Anthology of Young Illinois Poets by Tia Chucha Press. As a translator he performed two poems for the Brooks in Translation: A Gwendolyn Brooks Centennial Celebration at the Harold Washington Library in Chicago. Arocho was a featured poet at the 2016 Gerald Manley Hopkins International Poetry Festival in Kildare, Ireland. He is currently completing work on his forthcoming poetry manuscript, Nació Maestro.

This event is co-sponsored by CPL’s Poetry Committee.

How to Attend:

This workshops will be presented virtually online. You will need to download free Zoom software. Advance registration is required.

Do you need practice with your reading skills? Join Ms. Lina from the Thurgood Marshall Branch in this small group program for kids to read together.

This session is for kids who are just beginning to read on their own. These books have sight words, white space, phrases that repeat, simple sentences and pictures to support understanding.

Some examples are: Fox the Tiger by Corey R. Tabor, What This Story Needs Is A Pig in A Wig by Emma J. Virjan, and Go, Otto, Go! by David Milgrim.

program_name: Learning Circle: The Art of Storytelling with Pixar
program_description:
Join a multi week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. You’ll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. 

This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required. 

Please register for Virtual Learning Circle The Art of Storytelling with Pixar on the P2PU website for this learning course.

program_name: Rapbrary Book Discussion: Decoded by Jay Z
program_description:
Join CPL and the Richard M. Daley Branch as we read and discuss Decoded by Jay Z and enjoy renditions of his greatest hits from violinist Edith Yokley of the Chicago Sinfonietta's Resident Orchestra Project. We commemorate the 18th anniversary of Jay Z's the Black Album, and the 10 year anniversary of Decoded by Jay Z; a compelling work, that makes the case that Hip Hop lyrics are poetry. 

"Decoded is the autobiography and memoir of rapper Jay-Z, published by Random House and released November 16, 2010 on hardcover and November 1, 2011 on paperback. The book combines lyrics, their explanations, anecdotes, reflections, and autobiographical information. Jay-Z explains the three reasons why he wanted to write the book being a case for hip-hop lyrics as poetry, to tell a generational story turned into powerful experiences and revolved as a story everyone can relate to."

program_name: Adult Book Discussion: There There by Tommy Orange
program_description:
Celebrating Native American Heritage Month, Pullman Branch Library will discuss There There by Tommy Orange. 

One of the New York Times' 10 Best Books of 2019, There There follows twelve characters from Native communities as they travel to the Big Oakland Powwow.  Poignant, unflinching, and unforgettable, There There has been hailed as an instant, multi-generational classic.

program_name: Silver Screen Classics: Arsenic and Old Lace (1944)
program_description:
Mortimer Brewster (Cary Grant), a writer who has an aversion tomarriage falls for girl-next-door Elaine Harper (Priscilla Lane), and marry onHalloween. When the newlyweds return to deliver the news, a small celebrationis planned by his eccentric aunts, Abby (Josephine Hull), Martha(Jean Adair), and Teddy, (John Alexander), Mortimer’s brother who believes heis Theodore Roosevelt.

While looking in the window seat for notes to hisnext book, Mortimer discovers a body hidden there. To cap off thisnight of mayhem, brother Jonathan Brewster (Raymond Massey), on the run fromthe law, arrives with his personal plastic surgeon, Dr. Hermann Einstein (PeterLorie). They have also brought a “guest”, Mr. Spinoza who ends up in the windowseat.

How long will these uninvited guests stay? What other secrets do the Brewster sisters have? And will Mortimer and Elaine ever leave on their honeymoon? With Director Frank Capra at the helm, Arsenic and Old Lace is classic comedic theater.

© Warner Bros.- 118 minute -Rated NR

This month, the African American Heritage Committee is hosting an adult book discussion for CPL's One Book One Chicago selection, Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May.

After fourteen years in prison, Gerald “Stew Pot” Reeves, age thirty-one, returns home to live with his mom in Parkland, a black middle-class neighborhood on Chicago’s South Side. A frightening delinquent before being sent away (his infamies included butchering a neighbor’s cat, torching another neighbor’s garage, and terrorizing the locals with a scary pit bull named Hitler), his return sends Parkland residents into a religiously infused tailspin, which only increases when Stew Pot announces that he experienced a religious awakening in prison. Most neighbors are skeptical of this claim, with one notable exception: Mrs. Motley, a widowed retiree, and the Reeves’s next-door neighbor who loans Stew Pot a Bible, which is seen by Stew Pot and many in the community as a friendly gesture (Goodreads, 2021).

program_name: The Visual Record: An Introduction to the South Side Home Movie Project
program_description:
Home movies capture a range of details about everyday neighborhood life in Chicago, from fashion to food to the ways people walk down the street. They also provide unique evidence of the ways in which people represent themselves on camera, precursors to the “selfies” of today. Join the South Side Home Movie Project for an introduction to this unique initiative to collect, preserve, digitize and exhibit amateur films from Chicago’s South Side neighborhoods. Featuring film clips from the 1920s-1980s, this session invites attendees to imagine new ways of activating and preserving community knowledge through home movies. Families who have donated their films to the SSHMP will be on hand to narrate their films and share the experience of preserving their home movies and seeing them on screen for the first time in decades.

How to Attend:

This event will be presented virtually online. You will need to download free Zoom software. Advance registration is required.

program_name: Reading Came First Book Club: The Great Believers
program_description:
Join us as we honor the many lives lost to the AIDS Crisis during December, read and discuss The Great Believers by Rebecca Makkai.

"In 1985, Yale Tishman, the development director for a Chicago art gallery, is about to pull off a coup, bringing an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings. Yet as his career begins to flourish, the carnage of the AIDs epidemic grows around him. One by one, his friends are dying and after his friend Nico’s funeral, the virus circles closer and closer to Yale himself. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico’s little sister.

Thirty years later, Fiona is in Paris tracking down her estranged daughter who disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend, a famous photographer who documented the Chicago epidemic, she finds herself finally grappling with the devastating ways the AIDS crisis affected her life and her relationship with her daughter. Yale and Fiona’s intertwining stories take us through the heartbreak of 80’s and the chaos of the modern world, as both struggle to find goodness in the midst of disaster."

program_name: Make and Care Drop-In Studio with ArtWorks
program_description:
Join us the first three Wednesdays of every month to engage in self and collective care through arts and crafts making. This is an opportunity to commit time to your art/craft practice, meet new people, and support one another for the sake of mutual care and wellbeing.

At the virtual drop-in studio, you can use any arts or crafts materials you have on hand to make whatever you’d like, though there will be a weekly theme at the ready if you need some inspiration. Come learn from and share art/craft skills or creative tips with other participants and enjoy a supportive arts environment for makers of all skill levels.

program_name: The Art of Storytelling: Hybrid Virtual and In-Person Learning Circle
program_description:
THE ART OF STORYTELLING LEARNING CIRCLE

How would you tell the story of your community? Strengthen your storytelling skills with a learning circle this fall!

Do you know you can take an online course at the library in a learning circle? A learning circle is a study group for learners who want to complete online courses, together with others. This is a free opportunity for adults to learn new skills with others.  Learning Circles are presented as multi-week courses, and you should plan to attend each of the classes.

Join a five part course focused on the art of telling your story. You’ll join with others to learn the tools of the storytelling trade and write your own original story or poems! We will cover a new topic each week, focusing on story structure, point-of-view, characterization, description, and style. 

This course will take place virtually and in person. Capacity is limited. Registration is required and COVID-19 safety protocols will be followed for in-person attendance. If taking this learning circle virtually, you will need free Zoom software.

Accessibility
Need captioning for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 10 business days before the event.

This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Season Finale: Eric Charles May, author of Bedrock Faith, interviewed by Donna Seaman
program_description:
Celebrate the season finale of One Book, One Chicago’s 20th year with a very special conversation. Eric Charles May, author of Bedrock Faith, joins Booklist Editor Donna Seaman for a conversation about his writing, the book, and Chicago as a character. 

Eric Charles May is an associate professor in the Fiction Writing at Columbia College Chicago. A Chicago native and former reporter for the Washington Post, his fiction has appeared in the magazines Fish Stories, F, and Criminal Class. In addition to his Post reporting, his nonfiction has appeared in Sport Literate, the Chicago Tribune, and the personal essay anthology Briefly Knocked Unconscious by a Low-Flying Duck. Bedrock Faith, the 2021 One Book, One Chicago selection, is his first novel.


How to Attend:

This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel. and CPL's Facebook page. You'll be able to ask questions during the event as well!
Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later as well.

Accessibility

Automatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

This event is part of the One Book, One Chicago 2021 season, exploring the theme "Neighborhoods: Our City's Bedrock" and the book Bedrock Faith by Eric Charles May. For more information visit www.onebookonechicago.org

program_name: Adult Classics Book Club: The Talented Mr. Ripley
program_description:
The Lincoln Park Branch's Adult Classics Book Club will discuss Patricia Highsmith's The Talented Mr. Ripley.

In a chilling literary hall of mirrors, Patricia Highsmith introduces Tom Ripley. Like a hero in a latter-day Henry James novel, he is sent to Italy with a commission to coax a prodigal young American back to his wealthy father. But Ripley finds himself very fond of Dickie Greenleaf. He wants to be like him--exactly like him. Suave, agreeable, and utterly amoral, Ripley stops at nothing--certainly not only one murder--to accomplish his goal. Turning the mystery form inside out, Highsmith shows the terrifying abilities afforded to a man unhindered by the concept of evil.

Copies are available at Lincoln Park's Circulation Desk.

Join us as we discuss The Tiger by John Vaillant.  Deep in the evergreen woods of the Siberian Taiga, there roams a beast whose prowess and ferocity rivals that of the fictional Great White shark, Jaws. This is The Tiger—a half-ton, eight-feet long, apex predator who has developed a taste for the humans living in this remote wilderness. After a series of maulings, the villagers call for help is answered by Yuri Trush and his team of tiger inspectors. Now the hunt is on and author John Vaillant takes the reader along every step of the way, from the snow-packed tiger tracks winding through the largest boreal forest on Earth to the echoic halls of the Kremlin, looking for answers to questions about deforestation, natural law, and perhaps the most important: Where and when will The Tiger strike next?

Copies of this month's selection will be available 30 days prior to the event at the 6th floor reference desk at Harold Washington Library Center (400 South State Street, Chicago IL, 60605).

program_name: Author Jacquelin Thomas Discusses The Prodigal Book Series
program_description:
Jacquelin Thomas is an award-winning, best-selling author with 85+ published titles. A few of her recent releases are: Return to Me,  Another Chance With You, and Jezebel. She has published in the romance, women’s fiction, inspirational and young adult genres. Her books have garnered several awards, including two EMMA awards, the Romance In Color Reviewers Award, Readers Choice Award and the Atlanta Choice Award in the Religious & Spiritual category. Jacquelin was a 2005 honoree at the Houston Black Film Festival for the movie adaptation of her novel, Hidden Blessings. She was the first recipient to receive the Writers Achievement Award at the North Carolina Book Festival in Winston-Salem. She also received a Lifetime Achievement Award from Romantic Times Magazine. Jacquelin will discuss The Prodigal Series: The Prodigal Husband, Defining Moments, and Unexpected Serenity (available September 30, 2021).

program_name: Reading Came First Book Club: The Great Believers
program_description:
Join us as we honor the many lives lost to the AIDS Crisis during December, read and discuss The Great Believers by Rebecca Makkai.

"In 1985, Yale Tishman, the development director for a Chicago art gallery, is about to pull off a coup, bringing an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings. Yet as his career begins to flourish, the carnage of the AIDs epidemic grows around him. One by one, his friends are dying and after his friend Nico’s funeral, the virus circles closer and closer to Yale himself. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico’s little sister.

Thirty years later, Fiona is in Paris tracking down her estranged daughter who disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend, a famous photographer who documented the Chicago epidemic, she finds herself finally grappling with the devastating ways the AIDS crisis affected her life and her relationship with her daughter. Yale and Fiona’s intertwining stories take us through the heartbreak of 80’s and the chaos of the modern world, as both struggle to find goodness in the midst of disaster."

program_name: Make and Care Drop-In Studio with ArtWorks
program_description:
Join us the first three Wednesdays of every month to engage in self and collective care through arts and crafts making. This is an opportunity to commit time to your art/craft practice, meet new people, and support one another for the sake of mutual care and wellbeing.

At the virtual drop-in studio, you can use any arts or crafts materials you have on hand to make whatever you’d like, though there will be a weekly theme at the ready if you need some inspiration. Come learn from and share art/craft skills or creative tips with other participants and enjoy a supportive arts environment for makers of all skill levels.

program_name: Reading Came First Book Club: The Great Believers
program_description:
Join us as we honor the many lives lost to the AIDS Crisis during December, read and discuss The Great Believers by Rebecca Makkai.

"In 1985, Yale Tishman, the development director for a Chicago art gallery, is about to pull off a coup, bringing an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings. Yet as his career begins to flourish, the carnage of the AIDs epidemic grows around him. One by one, his friends are dying and after his friend Nico’s funeral, the virus circles closer and closer to Yale himself. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico’s little sister.

Thirty years later, Fiona is in Paris tracking down her estranged daughter who disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend, a famous photographer who documented the Chicago epidemic, she finds herself finally grappling with the devastating ways the AIDS crisis affected her life and her relationship with her daughter. Yale and Fiona’s intertwining stories take us through the heartbreak of 80’s and the chaos of the modern world, as both struggle to find goodness in the midst of disaster."

program_name: Make and Care Drop-In Studio with ArtWorks
program_description:
Join us the first three Wednesdays of every month to engage in self and collective care through arts and crafts making. This is an opportunity to commit time to your art/craft practice, meet new people, and support one another for the sake of mutual care and wellbeing.

At the virtual drop-in studio, you can use any arts or crafts materials you have on hand to make whatever you’d like, though there will be a weekly theme at the ready if you need some inspiration. Come learn from and share art/craft skills or creative tips with other participants and enjoy a supportive arts environment for makers of all skill levels.

program_name: Book Discussion: Confessions of an Ugly Stepsister by Gregory Maguire
program_description:
Join us as we discuss Confessions of An Ugly Stepsister by Gregory Maguire.

We all have heard the story of Cinderella, the beautiful child cast out to slave among the ashes. But, what about her stepsisters? The homely pair exiled into ignominy by the fame of their lovely sibling? Author Gregory Maguire invites the reader to hear the other side of the story, the story of the ugly stepsister.

Copies of the book are available at the Budlong Woods Branch circulation desk.

program_name: Adult Book Club: The Starless Sea
program_description:
Join the Merlo Branch Adult Book Club for a discussion of The Starless Sea by Erin Morgentern.

"Zachary Ezra Rawlins is a graduate student in Vermont when he discovers a rare book hidden in the stacks. As he turns the pages, entranced by tales of lovelorn prisoners, key collectors, and nameless acolytes, he reads something strange: a story from his own childhood. Bewildered by this inexplicable book and desperate to make sense of how his own life came to be recorded, Zachary uncovers a series of clues--a bee, a key, and a sword--that lead him to a masquerade party in New York, to a secret club, and through a doorway to a subterranean library, hidden far below the surface of the earth. What Zachary finds in this curious place is more than just a buried home for books and their guardians--it is a place of lost cities and seas of honey, lovers who pass notes under doors and across time, and of stories whispered by the dead. Zachary learns of those who have sacrificed much to protect this realm, relinquishing their sight and their tongues to preserve this archive, and also those who are intent on its destruction. Together with Mirabel, a fierce, pink-haired protector of the place, and Dorian, a beautiful barefoot man with shifting alliances, Zachary travels the twisting tunnels, darkened stairwells, crowded ballrooms, and sweetly-soaked shores of this magical world, discovering his purpose--in both the rare book and in his own life."

program_name: Reading Came First Book Club: The Great Believers
program_description:
Join us as we honor the many lives lost to the AIDS Crisis during December, read and discuss The Great Believers by Rebecca Makkai.

"In 1985, Yale Tishman, the development director for a Chicago art gallery, is about to pull off a coup, bringing an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings. Yet as his career begins to flourish, the carnage of the AIDs epidemic grows around him. One by one, his friends are dying and after his friend Nico’s funeral, the virus circles closer and closer to Yale himself. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico’s little sister.

Thirty years later, Fiona is in Paris tracking down her estranged daughter who disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend, a famous photographer who documented the Chicago epidemic, she finds herself finally grappling with the devastating ways the AIDS crisis affected her life and her relationship with her daughter. Yale and Fiona’s intertwining stories take us through the heartbreak of 80’s and the chaos of the modern world, as both struggle to find goodness in the midst of disaster."

program_name: Adult Book Club: Miseducated by Brandon P. Fleming
program_description:
This month, South Chicago Branch will read Miseducated by Brandon P. Fleming.

Through his personal narrative, readers witness Fleming's personal transformation, self-education, and how he takes what he learns about words and power to help others like himself. Not a "10 steps to personal transformation" or "how to go from the 'hood to Harvard." Miseducated is an honest personal narrative about resilience, visibility, role models, and overcoming all expectations (Goodreads,2021).

This month, we're reading Deacon King Kong by James McBride.

In September 1969, a fumbling, cranky old church deacon known as Sportcoat shuffles into the courtyard of the Cause Houses housing project in south Brooklyn, pulls a .38 from his pocket, and in front of everybody shoots the project's drug dealer at point-blank range.

In Deacon King Kong, McBride brings to vivid life the people affected by the shooting: the victim, the African-American and Latinx residents who witnessed it, the white neighbors, the local cops assigned to investigate, the members of the Five Ends Baptist Church where Sportcoat was a deacon, the neighborhood's Italian mobsters, and Sportcoat himself. (Goodreads, 2021).
